dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone in a vast, serrated mountain range a hundred miles north of Los Angeles, it looks from the outside like a ru sprawl. The day is a gold sliver in a navy sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Writer DALTON TRUMBO, 41, debonair, heartfelt and combati is naked in a tub, his copyholder on a wood plank as the steam rises. INT. LAZY-T RANCH - TRUMBO’S STUDY - DAWN Like the whole home, beautifully appointed. Trumbo, kindl cigarette in its holder, attacks the keys of a typewriter his desk, the fastest two-fingered typist ever as we --

dialogues.speaker: QUICKLY CUT AROUND HIS OFFICE,
dialogues.text: Taking in: - The American Booksellers National Book Award for his no Johnny Got His Gun. - The poster for his movie, Thirty Seconds Over Tokyo. - His Oscar nomination for the screenplay of Kitty Foyle. TIGHT ON TRUMBO’S TYPEWRITER As the inky letters CHOP movie dialogue across the white paper, Trumbo writing like a boxer working a speed bag -- MANNY: What do you want? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MORE QUICK POPS
dialogues.text: Thick with framed photos of: - Trumbo with KATHARINE HEPBURN at a United Refugee Commi dinner. - Trumbo as a World War II correspondent in his dress uniform, boarding a plane. - Trumbo in muddy fatigues, among battered SOLDIERS on a battle-scarred beach in the South Pacific. BACK TO A TIGHT CLOSE-UP OF TRUMBO’S WRITING Words racing across the page: What we all want.

dialogues.speaker: ATOP HIS DESK
dialogues.text: In them, WE SEE both Trumbo’s furious pecking reflected o glass, animatedly overlaying stills under glass of: - Trumbo’s wife Cleo in a stunning portrait. - Trumbo and Cleo with their three children, blowing out Niki’s eighth birthday cake.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO TRUMBO AT THE TYPEWRITER
dialogues.text: Lemony morning light now paints the windows. Trumbo write To not die young, poor... And now we HEAR --

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: What do you want? What we all want. To not die young, poor... -- as the final words of Trumbo’s speech strike paper -- -..or alone. -- Trumbo SLAPS the return and in a WHITE BLUR we’re now

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: +..or alone. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: EDWARD G. ROBINSON -- a charismatic, stocky man of 53, bo assertive and refined -- plays “MANNY,” stepping from a sedan, moving toward a SUPPORTING PLAYER as “ROCCO,” on h knees, bloody lip, torn jacket. “ROCCO” Manny, these guys... I don’t give ‘em what they’re after, they'll kill me. EDWARD G. ROBINSON/“MANNY” Hold it, Rocco. “Manny” takes out his revolver -- and aims it at “Rocco,” freezes as he stands. EDWARD G. ROBINSON/”MANNY” (CONT’D) If we don’t fight these guys, sure, maybe you -- As “Manny” gestures with the gun, its cylinder dislodges the barrel -- and several bullets FLY out and comically CLATTER to the stage floor at Robinson’s feet. EDWARD G. ROBINSON/“MANNY” (CONT’D) Shit. The director is out of his chair and on his feet -- SAM W early 60s, sharp, authoritative.

dialogues.speaker: SAM WOOD
dialogues.text: Cut! Goin’ again, Eddie. A BELL sounds. The CREW rustles in the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: Sorry, Sam. Sorry, everybody. Of course, the one day the author’s among us. Trumbo sits nearby, in a bespoke suit, calmly smoking. Robinson settles in a canvas chair with his name on the b

dialogues.speaker: SAM WOOD
dialogues.text: (as he glides past to talk to the CAMERAMAN) “Among us.” Sure ain’t one of us.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: (keeping it light) What’s the brilliant line, Trumbo? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: “If we don’t fight these guys, sure, maybe you get that long, happy life we all want.”

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: Then what is it you’ve got me fighting for again?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: “Peace on Earth, good will toward men.” Nearby, Wood SNORTS. Yeah, right.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: You can’t do that, this is America.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: How about sex and money?

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: There you go, two things we all love. None of your little sermons on citizenship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flat half-acre dominated by a massive pool that GLOWS w a hundred floating candles. A PARTY where: - MEN are in black tie, WOMEN in gowns, everyone smokes, everyone drinks. Different time, different world. - There’s MUSIC from a live BIG BAND. VOICES overlap and compete as we snag snippets:

dialogues.speaker: PARTYGOER 1
dialogues.text: “,.-I don’t love it but Zanuck does...”

dialogues.speaker: PARTYGOER 2
dialogues.text: “,..make the Indians the good guys, that’s the twist...”

dialogues.speaker: PARTYGOER 3
dialogues.text: “Now the actors want to go on strike. Who’s next? Lassie?” CLEO TRUMBO, 30s, hovers at the edge of a GROUP OF WOMEN about her age. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She’s beautiful, observant, sensitive, often silent, as s is here, excusing herself with a warm smile to look for someone at the party, passing by -- A GROUP OF MEN. Louder, more boisterous. Within that grou Edward G. Robinson.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: (in mid-sentence) .+.Still doing reshoots, what else? Luckily, Mayer lined up the A Team, Sam Wood to shoot, Dalton Trumbo for rewrites, so, fingers crossed... From across the lawn, TWO MALE VOICES suddenly RISE, so w hear before we see:

dialogues.speaker: SAM WOOD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ...desus, Trumbo, a goddamn six- month strike, for what?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (dryly) Well, I think... money. Cleo Trumbo turns to that second VOICE with minor dread a as she does, she and Robinson clock one another with the thought: Jesus, here we go... As they both zero in on: Director Sam Wood, more than a little drunk.

dialogues.speaker: SAM WOOD
dialogues.text: Laugh it up. I had no crew! I couldn’t work -- (shouting at Trumbo) -- you wouldn't work, God forbid you cross a picket line. For set builders. What do set builders have to do with writing?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: What writers write, builders build. What they build, you film. You make all the money you possibly can, so do I, why shouldn’t they? And why can’t we help them? In the long run, it’s better for everyone - (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAM WOOD
dialogues.text: -- said the Swimming Pool Soviet.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: (calmly) Sam. You won. The strike’s over, the union’s history. We've all gone back to being good little worker bees making sweet movie honey and you -- (now, just a little sharp) -- might just try being a gracious winner. That last comes with a gentle poke into Wood’s lapel from Trumbo’s fingers, which hold his cigarette. Wood does not appreciate the jab or the accompanying smoke in his face.

dialogues.speaker: SAM WOOD
dialogues.text: It’s never over with you people -- strike, after strike, after strike!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wood is SHOUTING now. Among the Guests: HEADS turn... SMI falter... CONVERSATIONS stop.

dialogues.speaker: SAM WOOD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Y'know what? I’m going on strike -- against people WHO GO ON STRIKE!

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: And I won’t cross your picket line, either. Wood might just shove Trumbo now, he’s so angry, but -- -- suddenly, Robinson is there to get Wood’s arm in a friendly grasp.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: (with jovial aplomb) Sam, Sam, Sam, we've got to talk about those scenes tomorrow, disaster, who the hell wrote that crap? (a wink at Trumbo, steering Wood away) But first, may I have this dance...? At the same time, Cleo takes her husband’s hand and moves in the opposite direction. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Having fun?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Eternally. They kiss and move to the bar, passing -- -- a tall, broad MAN of 39 who eyes Trumbo the way a west sheriff would a gunfighter. We don’t know it yet, but: This is JOHN WAYNE. And as his eyes follow the Trumbos, he meets the gaze of WOMAN. Late middle years, trim, striking, grand yet folks always in a stylish hat. Wayne and she share a moment of silent understanding. We don’t know it yet, but: This is HEDDA HOPPER.

dialogues.speaker: UP ON THE MOVIE SCREEN
dialogues.text: Actual black & white documentary footage of a waving WINS CHURCHILL, grimly addressing an assembly:

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON CHURCHILL, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: Nobody knows what Soviet Russia intends to do. An Iron Curtain has descended across the continent. The newsreel CUTS TO a cartoon map of Europe and Asia as animated red Iron Curtain drops, enclosing Soviet Russia.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSREEL NARRATOR
dialogues.text: The front line in a new kind of war. A Cold War! SHOTS of Russian military might: ARMIES march, FIGHTERS launch, TANKS roll. NEWSREEL NARRATOR (CONT’D) The enemy -- Communists! BACK TO the cartoon map as the Iron Curtain BECOMES a ser of red tentacles -- NEWSREEL NARRATOR (CONT’D) Their goal -- world domination! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: -- and those tentacles slither across Europe and Asia, heading for the United States.

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE TO REVEAL
dialogues.text: MEN in ties, WOMEN in dresses, KIDS in their Sunday best. And among them WE FIND Dalton Trumbo with his family: daughter NIKI, 8, son CHRIS, 6, Cleo, and in her lap, the youngest, MITZI, 2, all munching and sipping movie treats watching --

dialogues.speaker: THE NEWSREEL
dialogues.text: As it CUTS TO A SHOT OF the Hollywood sign -- NEWSREEL NARRATOR (CONT’D) Dateline: Hollywood. The offices of former film starlet, now top columnist, Hedda Hopper. -- then DISSOLVES TO A SHOT of a newspaper column under t aerodynamically lettered byline, HEDDA HOPPER’S HOLLYWOOD Next to the text, Hedda Hopper. As she begins to speak fr inside her column:

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: (to camera) Greetings from our film capital, where all is sun and fun. Or is it?

dialogues.speaker: OF WELL-KNOWN MOVIE FOLK
dialogues.text: Grouped together a bit awkwardly in bright midday sun: HEDDA HOPPER (V.O.) (CONT’D) See the famous faces here? Danny Kaye, Humphrey Bogart, his dishy bride, Lauren Bacall, their good friend, film director John Huston, and many others... CLOSE-UPS (ARCHIVAL) of these FAMOUS FACES, plus a few LE WELL-KNOWN. HEDDA HOPPER (V.O.) (CONT’D) ...all of whom have declared solidarity with film crews picketing for higher wages. In walk-outs that quickly turned violent. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STUDIOS that indeed turn violent: POLICE CLUB THE STRIKER

dialogues.speaker: ATTACK DOGS MAUL, FIRE HOSES SPRAY --
dialogues.text: HEDDA HOPPER (V.O.) (CONT’D) Because these strikes were in fact the work of dangerous radicals. A NEW CLOSE-UP (TO BE SHOT) -- SOMEONE standing on an app box, addressing a peaceful line of studio PICKETERS: It’s Dalton Trumbo, his black & white face 40 feet high:

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: .--this is what angers and frightens the studios!

dialogues.speaker: DOWN IN THE THEATRE
dialogues.text: The Trumbo family is silently stunned. Trumbo’s own jaw slackens just a bit at the surreal sight of himself up on screen, then he quickly regains his composure. But his oldest child can’t help herself --

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: Dad, is that you? He nods curtly, pats her arm and the tiny, color, real Tr down here watches:

dialogues.speaker: THE ENORMOUS BLACK
dialogues.text: Delivering this searing union rallying cry to the assembl among whom we glimpse an APPLAUDING Edward G. Robinson:

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: We’ve discovered where our true power lies! Builders, cameramen, painters, drivers, writers, actors, directors! We are a single, indivisible brotherhood of workers. Bargain with a few of us, you bargain with all of us! Threaten one, you threaten us all and it’s war! We are many but from this day forward -- we are one! The Picketers and Movie Stars UP ON SCREEN begin to CHEER Trumbo as --

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is writer Dalton Trumbo. Who is... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A new CLOSE-UP of Hedda Hopper in her office:

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: .--like many of those strikers -- and their supporters -- a registered Communist.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO TRUMBO AND NIKI
dialogues.text: As daughter looks at father, surprised -- is that true? Trumbo doesn’t meet her questioning gaze, just smokes and stoically takes in:

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: Dwarfing him:

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: Which is why we must know: Who exactly was behind that walk-out... and why? The scene now CUTS TO various CONGRESSMEN, INVESTIGATORS AIDES mounting the stairs of the U.S. Capitol. HEDDA HOPPER (V.O.) (CONT’D) Our elected leaders will find out. The CAMERA SINGLES OUT a bald, fifty-ish New Jerseyite -- HEDDA HOPPER (V.O.) (CONT’D) Congressman J. Parnell Thomas and his House Un-American Activities Committee.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN THOMAS, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: Communism is not some faraway threat; its most dangerous agents are here, controlling the airwaves and movie screens, taking over its employees and their unions. They need to be identified as the enemies they are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The five Trumbos stream out with the audience. When suddenly --

dialogues.speaker: A YOUNG FATHER WITH HIS KIDS
dialogues.text: Hey, that you in the newsreel...? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 11.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: It was, yes -- The Father FLINGS Coke into Trumbo’s face, SPLATTERING hi

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG FATHER
dialogues.text: Traitor -- -- terrifying Cleo and the kids before taking off.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: (dripping, calm) No harm done, everybody okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mountain, meadow and sky dwarf this fine spread. Trumbo walks along the fence while Niki rides a horse next to hi

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: So, are you a Communist?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: Is it against the law?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: It is not.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: That lady with the big hat said you're a “dangerous radical.” Are you?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Radical, maybe. Dangerous, only to men who fling Cokes.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: You don’t want to overthrow the government?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: No, we have a good government. But anything good can be better, don’t you think?

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: Is Mom a Communist? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 12.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: Am I?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Let's give you the official test. Mom packs your favorite lunch...

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: Salami.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: .»..and you see someone at school with no lunch -- what do you do?

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: Share?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: You don’t tell them to get a job?

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: (aware she’s being teased) No.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Offer a loan at six percent?

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: Dad.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Then just ignore them.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: No. He studies his oldest daughter with great affection.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Well, well. You little Commie. INT. EDWARD G. ROBINSON’S MANSION - LIVING ROOM - NIGHT Elegant, tasteful, its walls glowing colorfully with: Six spotlit French Impressionist paintings. Seated under a Renoir, Trumbo is debating with Robinson and a small gathering of DIRECTORS, PRODUCERS, ACTORS and WRITERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 13.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: Trumbo, as usual, you only make sense to you. Let ‘em call you a Communist, me a Democrat -- both legitimate parties, yours is just meaner and duller but nothing illegal about any of it.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Yet.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: Hunter, tell your friend to dial down the paranoia and have a drink. This to screenwriter IAN McLELLAN HUNTER, 32, quick mind, eyes, sharp wit, always puffing on a pipe:

dialogues.speaker: IAN MCLELLAN HUNTER
dialogues.text: I don’t think he’s being paranoid enough.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: Not you, too. Trumbo pulls several booklets of mimeoed paper from a val

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: I’ve drawn up a little pamphlet. (passing them out) Subject: “Congress Unaware of Little Thing Called First Amendment.”

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They're aware... Everyone turns to the man saying:

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...they just don’t give a shit. ARLEN HIRD is 40s, caustic, dyspeptic; the BUTLER offerin him a canape, which he waves off --

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All they care about is this nice, new war of theirs -- these guys love war -- and this is a great one, scary, vague and expensive. Anybody for it’s a hero, anybody against it’s a traitor. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: And anybody who thinks it’s about movies is an idiot. Which is why I’m going to go have a chat with the other side.

dialogues.speaker: IAN MCLELLAN HUNTER
dialogues.text: You don’t mean the Alliance.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: I do. A CHORUS of disbelieving MOANS and startled LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: Are you out of your mind -- ?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: They're actors, writers, directors, just like us --

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: They're Nazis, they’re just too cheap to buy the uniforms --

dialogues.speaker: IAN MCLELLAN HUNTER
dialogues.text: They invited Congress out here --

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: (to the room at large) And are they all Sam Wood and Hedda Hopper? Let’s not demonize people we don’t really know.

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: Go for it. Be fun. ‘Cause ya know who you’re gonna be talkin’ to?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN WAYNE, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: I wanna say one thing about a place I love. No, not Hollywood... And WE REVEAL WE’RE --

dialogues.speaker: JOHN WAYNE
dialogues.text: .+.I like Hollywood... Alone on stage, John Wayne, six-feet, four inches of bass voiced movie icon. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 15.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JOHN WAYNE (CONT’D) -.-but I love America! As WE REVEAL a sign near the stage announcing this is:

dialogues.speaker: OF AMERICAN IDEALS
dialogues.text: WE SEE the HUGE CROWD of movie pros, from below-the-line to above-the-line stars, all CHEERING and APPLAUDING Wayn JOHN WAYNE (CONT’D) And when we talk about America I’m talking about freedom! The kinda freedom we just fought a world war to save! You wanna be a Commie, go be a Commie... but some friends of mine in Washington think you got some questions to answer!

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BACK OF THE ROOM
dialogues.text: Trumbo, Hird, Hunter and Edward G. Robinson all stand, studying Wayne, awed and disturbed by his power.

dialogues.speaker: IAN MCLELLAN HUNTER
dialogues.text: I never knew he was this good.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: ‘Cause he’s not acting, that’s him.

dialogues.speaker: UP ON STAGE
dialogues.text: Wayne’s voice RISES with the MOB’S CHEERS.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN WAYNE
dialogues.text: Still wanna be a Commie? Be a Commie! In Russia! But off ya go 'n’ enjoy the Bolshoi Ballet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo, Hird, Robinson and Hunter offer copies of Trumbo’ pamphlet to THOSE who ignore or shoot them dirty looks. O put on their hats and throw smug smiles. Including --

dialogues.speaker: SAM WOOD
dialogues.text: (as he accepts a pamphlet) Do svidaniya. Russian for “goodbye,” as he tears it to shreds. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 16.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: This? Is a nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: IAN MCLELLAN HUNTER
dialogues.text: If it were, I'd be in bed. An elegantly turned out, in-the-flesh Hedda Hopper approaches.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: Hello, Dalton.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Hedda, here you are, of course. Good evening to you.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: Eddie, darling.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: Hedda. New hat?

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: Daily, dear, daily. (to Trumbo) Been to the movies lately? (before he can answer) Duke! John Wayne has crossed the room with IATSE Union Leader R BREWER, 40, jowly, jovial and shrewd.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wasn’t he? Mag. Nificent.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN WAYNE
dialogues.text: Just sayin’ what needs sayin’. (then) Hiya, Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: Duke.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN WAYNE
dialogues.text: Hear you ‘n’ your pals got a “pamphlet.” Any takers?

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: Not yet... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: (offers one to Wayne) Would you like one? We’re Communists.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: (shrugs) He’s a writer.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN WAYNE
dialogues.text: (to Robinson) Ya won’t get any takers. Not here.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Why not? Wayne now turns and regards an affable Trumbo. DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) All it says is, Congress has no right to investigate how we vote, where we pray, what we think, say or make movies about. (holds out the pamphlet) Hello, I’m Dalton Trumbo.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN WAYNE
dialogues.text: (takes the pamphlet) Congress has the right to go after anything they think is a threat.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: We disagree. That’s the point -- we both have the right to be wrong. A LOOSE, CURIOUS GROUP has begun to gather, sensing troub

dialogues.speaker: JOHN WAYNE
dialogues.text: You wanna talk about rights, first show me whose side you're on. Russia’s no friend, not anymore. You better wake up. (then) ‘Cause it’s a new day. A new day.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN WAYNE
dialogues.text: Maybe it’s not for your kind.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: My kind, what kind is that? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN WAYNE
dialogues.text: Kind that has no idea why we just won a war. Wayne crumples Trumbo’s pamphlet, tosses it and starts of

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: That’s the second time you’ve brought that up. I was a war correspondent in Okinawa -- (to Hedda now) -- your son was stationed in the Philippines -- (re: Robinson) -- Eddie was in Europe with the Office of War Information -- (back to Wayne) -- where’d you serve again?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN WAYNE
dialogues.text: (stops, turns) You tryin’ to say something?

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: No, Duke, he wasn’t --

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: Stay out of it, Eddie --

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: (right in Wayne’s face) If you’re gonna talk about World War Two like you personally won it, let’s be clear where you were stationed -- on a film set, shooting blanks, wearing makeup and if you’re going to hit me, I'd like to take my glasses off. Wayne could belt him but camera FLASHBULBS POP.

dialogues.speaker: ROY BREWER
dialogues.text: Duke, let’s get outta here... He urges the apoplectic Wayne to a doorway.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: Thank you, Dalton. My next column just wrote itself. She exits. Robinson, Hird and Hunter just stare at Trumbo (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: (happy as a clam) That was... I don’t even know what to...

dialogues.speaker: IAN MCLELLAN HUNTER
dialogues.text: Yes, good thing you don’t want to demonize anybody or that could’ve been awkward. EXT. MGM STUDIOS —- DAY Walking with Robinson, Trumbo crosses the gleaming, BUSY dream factory at the height of its productivity, stops at newsstand to buy cigarettes and is confronted by a strang and awful sight: The face of Hedda Hopper on the July 28, 1947 cover of TI magazine, the copies all hung in a line, creating two doz identical Heddas. Trumbo is quietly amused, Robinson slightly horrified.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: Good God. (reaches for a copy) Trumbo, you pick your enemies the way you live -- only the best will do. INT. MGM STUDIOS - LOUIS B. MAYER’S OFFICE - DAY LOUIS B. MAYER, 60, warm-hearted, cold-blooded studio president, beams affectionately at Trumbo.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS B. MAYER
dialogues.text: Your next deal’s gonna make you the highest-paid writer in Hollywood, which’'1l make you the highest-paid writer in the world. BUDDY ROSS, early 30s, a young, go-getter producer, sits to the side, eyes darting anxiously between the studio president and the writer.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS B. MAYER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You earned it. You don’t just write happy endings, you actually believe them.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY ROSS
dialogues.text: That’s what the people pay to see, that’s why you belong here at MGM, right, L.B.? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 20.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Look, I hate to make the wooing too easy for you but: Where do I sign?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS B. MAYER
dialogues.text: Just one thing. If you’re going to work for me... (unfolds a newspaper) ...I never, ever want to see anything like this... HEDDA HOPPER’S HOLLYWOOD column: a photo of Dalton Trumbo under the headline, “OUR OWN RED MENACE.”

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS B. MAYER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ..-again. Trumbo and Mayer lock eyes. Buddy is frozen silent.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: You won’t. I promise. Mayer nods, satisfied. Buddy could kiss Trumbo. DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) Just stop reading Hedda Hopper. Off Mayer's fury and Buddy’s panic --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Overlooking their lake. Trumbo stands at a hot grill, flipping filet of trout, holding court for his family; Hunter, his WIFE and CHILDREN; Robinson and his WIFE; Bud Ross and a GLAMOROUS INGENUE GIRLFRIEND.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: (to Cleo) Mom, please...?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: (to Niki) Not now, honey.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: So what'd L.B. say then?

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY ROSS
dialogues.text: Jesus, don’t, I haven’t eaten since. My job’s not hard enough?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Your job’s not hard at all. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 21.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY ROSS
dialogues.text: You think getting Mayer to sign you after those headlines was easy? You have a record-breaking, three- year contract -- to make shit up. You’re welcome.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: C'mon, Mom!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A solitary black sedan churns up a plume of dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo and the other adults LAUGH and drink away a dazzli summer afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: (to Robinson) She really can! Ask her!

dialogues.speaker: IAN MCLELLAN HUNTER
dialogues.text: (chuckling) Cleo? Is this true?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: I... had a very unusual mother.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Which means “Stage Mother.” He picks up a glass, a twinkle in his eye.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: (knows what’s coming, laughs, embarrassed) Trumbo, no... He hands Niki the glass, who tosses it to Cleo, which she catches easily, then another, which she catches in her ot hand, beginning to lightly JUGGLE the two, causing the children to finally SQUEAL with delight as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- that black sedan takes a gravel-popping turn and --  TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Robinson and his Wife stare in amazement, watching Cle expertly JUGGLE two glasses, flipping and catching one be her back as Trumbo beams.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: The misspent youth of a child acrobat.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: My God, how long were you in show business?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: (juggling away) Till I was 15. And it was more “show-forced-labor.” Niki tosses her mother a third glass, which Cleo catches, pinwheeling all three easily.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: She never drops one, ever.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Mom had a little saying. “Drop it, you lose your next meal.”

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: (to Robinson) And “Mom” wasn’t kidding. Woman was a Dickensian harridan.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: (laughs) No one even knows what that means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The black sedan closes in --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- as Cleo does over-hand grabs, then switches to a circu pattern, the spool of tumblers catching sunlight in dazzl prisms. AND THROUGH CLEO’S GLASSY WHIRL OF COLOR - WE SEE THAT SE Pull to a stop and Trumbo sees THREE MEN in suits get out  TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Family and friends watching, Trumbo greets the three men, among whom we recognize: HUAC Investigator Robert Stripli

dialogues.speaker: STRIPLING
dialogues.text: Mr. Dalton Trumbo? Stripling hands Trumbo a pink document.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congressman J. Parnell Thomas stands before REPORTERS:

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN THOMAS
dialogues.text: Nineteen subpoenas have been issued to those we believe have knowledge of the ongoing Communist threat in Hollywood. This announcement is greeted with a resounding... pause.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 1
dialogues.text: Uh, what kind of threat is that?

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN THOMAS
dialogues.text: A conspiracy to corrupt democratic values and bring about the overthrow of this nation.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 2
dialogues.text: Using... movies. The CHUCKLING Reporters clearly think this is horseshit.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 1
dialogues.text: Any movie in particular or...?

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN THOMAS
dialogues.text: (cutting him off) Movies are the most powerful form of influence ever created and they are infested with hidden traitors who will be dragged into the light, for all to see and all to judge.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: HEDDA HOPPER’S HOLLYWOOD NEWSREEL Her talking face again appears alongside her column. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 24.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: (to camera) We travel now...

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: And actual newsreel footage in black & white of the Capit packed with POLITICIANS, EXECUTIVES and STARS.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .-.to Washington, D.C., where battle lines are drawn. On one side, Communist subversives. On the other, studio heads, labor leaders and some of our brightest stars. And in actual footage from his testimony that day, RONALD REAGAN, 36, handsome and measured, cooperates with Robert Stripling before a PACKED HOUSE.

dialogues.speaker: STRIPLING
dialogues.text: Your profession, Mr. Reagan?

dialogues.speaker: RONALD REAGAN
dialogues.text: Motion picture actor.

dialogues.speaker: STRIPLING
dialogues.text: And you are currently the president of the Screen Actors Guild?

dialogues.speaker: RONALD REAGAN
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: STRIPLING
dialogues.text: Has it been reported to you that certain members of the guild were Communists?

dialogues.speaker: RONALD REAGAN
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, I have heard different discussions of some of them as Communists.

dialogues.speaker: JUMP CUT TO
dialogues.text: More actual news footage -- CONGRESSMAN RICHARD M. NIXON California), 34. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 25.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD M. NIXON
dialogues.text: Do you believe that the motion picture industry is doing everything it can to rid itself of subversive, Un-American influences? Then answering, in testimony we recreate in matching blac white --

dialogues.speaker: ROY BREWER
dialogues.text: No! The Communists are everywhere! They report directly to Moscow! Then --

dialogues.speaker: SAM WOOD
dialogues.text: Enough is enough! The Communists have to go!

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: What we’re about to do...

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: ...won’t make us too popular. Trumbo leads a small strategy session with Robert Kenny, Arlen Hird and a HALF-DOZEN of the SUBPOENAED 19 and -- -- Niki, in a corner, quietly taking everything in. DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) Our support’s not only going to vanish, we’re going to get attacked by our own.

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: Okay, we get slandered, then what?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT KENNY
dialogues.text: You testify and answer every question they ask, in your own way.

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: So don’t tell ‘em shit.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Beautifully put. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 26.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: In her corner, Niki smiles.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Of the nineteen forced to appear, only ten were called to the stand. The Hollywood Nineteen wait to be called to testify.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dubbed “The Hollywood Ten,” they refused to answer every question about their Communist ties.

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: You know what that’s called?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Contempt of Congress. Beat. The room is silent, Niki transfixed. Then --

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: Maybe I’m missing something, ‘cause all I’m seein’ here is jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Trumbo is sworn in, there’s a BLINDING CAMERA FLASH an Congress, the crowds and Trumbo all BURST INTO FULL COLOR

dialogues.speaker: STRIPLING
dialogues.text: Mr. Trumbo, I will ask various questions, all of which can be answered yes or no.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: I shall answer yes or no if I please to. Many questions can only be answered yes or no by a moron or a slave. As the caucus room FLUTTERS with DISBELIEVING MOANS, supportive LAUGHTER and a few nasty BOOS, WE FIND -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 27.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Cleo Trumbo, in the gallery, serenely unsurprised by her husband’s insolence.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT KENNY
dialogues.text: No one can beat Congress in Congress. The only place to do that’s in court --

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: -- in front of a judge who'll probably hate Commies and rule against us --

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: -- in a lower court, yes, we'll likely lose but on appeal...

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT KENNY
dialogues.text: ...-it’ll work. The Supreme Court is a five to four liberal majority. They think the Committee's unconstitutional, they want it killed and we’re gonna hand them the case to do it.

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: Great. Best of luck. I’m out. And suddenly, Hird is on his feet and gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitzi SPLASHES in the water with Chris as Cleo aims a lar professional camera at them and snaps pictures. Arlen Hird walks to a nearby tree, leans against it and s a cigarette into his mouth. Trumbo walks up.

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: (sighs, beat) Look, I can’t afford what you’re talkin’ about... Supreme Court, legal fees. My wife, it’s never been great, but I raid our savings for this? She’s gone, with both boys. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 28.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: I’ll cover you. Expenses, travel, legal fees... Hird is shocked by Trumbo’s casual generosity.

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: You don’t even like me.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: I like you fine, you don’t like me.

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: Also, I don’t trust you.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: I'd say “go on,” but I’m afraid you will.

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: Look. I know what I am, okay? I want this country to be a whole new... everything. Top to bottom. And if I get what I want? Nobody gets their own lake.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Seems a little grim.

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: For you, yeah. But not the guys who built all this... (the ranch, the lake) .-.for you, their families, friends. Which, remember, is kind of the point. Them, not you. I mean, if I’m wrong here, tell me, but ever since I’ve known you, you talk like a radical, live like a rich guy --

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: True.

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: -- ‘'n’ I don’t think if it gets right down to it, you're willing to lose all this just to do what’s right. Radical would, rich guy? I don’t think so. Trumbo watches his family in the sparkling light of his l (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Am I “willing.” Hm. (beat) Well. I hate martyrs and will not fight a lost cause, so you're right, I’m not willing to lose it all -- I’m willing to risk it. That's why being the radical and the rich guy is the perfect combination. The radical may fight

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: with the purity of Jesus... but the rich guy wins with the cunning of Satan.

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: Y'know, the thing is, really? You’re wrong about almost everything and you never shut up.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN THOMAS, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: No, no, no, no -- }

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still in glorious color that reveals the face of Congress Thomas to be red as a blister as he POUNDS his gavel --

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN THOMAS
dialogues.text: -- no, no, no, no, no, no! -- like a four year old throwing a tantrum. CONGRESSMAN THOMAS (CONT’D) Are you now or have you ever been a member of the Communist party?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Mr. Stripling, may I read a statement?

dialogues.speaker: STRIPLING
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: May I present my writing?

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN THOMAS
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: May I -- ? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 30.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN THOMAS
dialogues.text: No, no, no! Answer the question!

dialogues.speaker: STRIPLING
dialogues.text: Are you now or have you ever been a member of the Communist Party?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Have I been accused of a crime? If so, what is it and where is your evidence?

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN THOMAS
dialogues.text: You’re not asking the questions!

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Well, I was.

dialogues.speaker: STRIPLING
dialogues.text: The witness will answer.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: I see. And then what would you like? My voting record, union membership, religion?

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN THOMAS
dialogues.text: Answer the question!

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: You believe this Committee has the right to compel testimony, indict opinion --

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN THOMAS
dialogues.text: Typical Communist tactics!

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: -- criminalize thought -- but that right does not exist and the day it does, God help us all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Arlen Hird is now on the stand.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN THOMAS
dialogues.text: Are you now or have you ever been a member of the Communist party? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 31.

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: Congressman, first I need to call my doctor.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN THOMAS
dialogues.text: Your doctor? I don’t un --

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: To see if he can surgically remove my conscience. EXPLOSIVE LAUGHTER no amount of GAVELLING by Thomas can s Trumbo sits beside Cleo in the gallery, delighted and surprised. And our HEARING MONTAGE ENDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo and Hird walk as Hird begins to COUGH, can’t stop.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: What? What is it?

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: Cancer.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Jesus. How long’ve you known?

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: Couple months.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Months? Are you being treated -- ?

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: I don’t like the options. It’s lung cancer. Bad if they operate, bad if they don’t.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Is there anything I can do?

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: No! No. It’s cancer, Jesus. (then) Yes. Make sure this fuckin’ plan of yours works.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 32.

dialogues.speaker: A HEADLINE FROM NOVEMBER 24, 1947
dialogues.text: THE NEW YORK TIMES: “’HOLLYWOOD 10’ CHARGED WITH CONTEMPT CONGRESS” Under that, a group photo of The Hollywood Ten, PUSHING I the grainy faces of Hird and Trumbo. INT. MGM STUDIOS - LOUIS B. MAYER’S OFFICE - DAY Other faces, in framed photos on a wall: CLARK GABLE, JUD GARLAND, FRED ASTAIRE, more. Being studied by Hedda Hoppe Mayer enters, sees Hedda is focused on a group photo with row of SILENT STARS where, squeezed between RAMON NAVARRO GRETA GARBO, a younger Hedda stands alongside a boyish Ma

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: Look at us. God, we thought we knew everything...

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS B. MAYER
dialogues.text: We did.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: Not me. (then) I didn’t know how much I loved it all, till I hit a certain birthday and the parts started drying up. I remember thinking, when you love something and it stops loving you back, what do you do...?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS B. MAYER
dialogues.text: You fight.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: That’s a man’s answer. (he concedes, waits) You love it more. Till it surrenders.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS B. MAYER
dialogues.text: Well. You never left MGM. Or my heart. How’s your boy? Still in the Navy?

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: First lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS B. MAYER
dialogues.text: You raised a real hero. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 33.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: Which is why I’d like to tell him we're doing as much for this country as he is. (then) Are we?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS B. MAYER
dialogues.text: It’s complicated. Trumbo, the others, all have contracts...

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: You helped build this business, so did I, we’re not gonna watch these pissants defile it --

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS B. MAYER
dialogues.text: I’m running a studio here, you think I love every person on my payroll? Grow up.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: Then how about I make crystal clear to my thirty-five million readers who runs Hollywood and won’t fire these traitors? How about I name names, real names? Like yours, Lazar Meir; or Jack Warner, Jacob Varner; Sam Goldwyn, Schmuel Gelbfisz --

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS B. MAYER
dialogues.text: You watch what you say to me --

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: No, you watch! This isn’t 1920! I’m not your STARLET, you don’t tell me what to do! Never, ever, ever, ever, EVER AGAIN!

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS B. MAYER
dialogues.text: Enough, Hedda --

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: Forty years ago, you're starving in some shtetl, the greatest country on Earth takes you in, gives you wealth, power and the second we need you, you do nothing! (then) Just what my readers expect from a business run by kikes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 34.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS B. MAYER
dialogues.text: Get out. She sits. Takes a cigarette out of her case. Lights it. She blows a wall of smoke between them.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: Now listen, L.B. I’m fond of you. Some of my happiest years were spent on this lot. (then) Not in your office, of course, you always trying to fuck me on the couch, me maintaining my virtue. Barely. (lightly) But... times change. Now I’1l happily fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. MGM STUDIOS - LOUIS B. MAYER’S OFFICE - DAY Black & white NEWSREEL, created by us, of Mayer, flanked the other studio heads, reading a press statement to camera:

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS B. MAYER
dialogues.text: Forthwith, all studios unanimously agree to discharge the Hollywood Ten. Without compensation. Effective immediately. (then) Further, no studio will ever employ a member of the Communist Party or anyone refusing to cooperate in our mighty struggle against this terrible new menace. INT. HEDDA HOPPER’S OFFICE - DAY Hedda reads her copy into a large microphone.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: He’s been loved by film fans for almost twenty years. But have you noticed? He hasn’t been on-screen much lately. Bad box office? No. Bad politics. Bad news indeed. For Mr. Edward G. Robinson. INT. EDWARD G. ROBINSON’S MANSION - LIVING ROOM - DAY Robinson addresses a small GROUP, many of whom would rath not be here. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 35.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: The Hollywood Ten’s going to court for all of us. It’1ll be long, expensive. So please, give as much as you can to the defense fund.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: The gathering has thinned. Trumbo studies Robinson's Impressionist paintings. Robinson wanders over with Cleo.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: This little gathering doesn’t quite have the zip and zing of yesteryear, does it?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Where’re all the liberals all of a sudden?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: At their lawyers’. Or psychiatrists’.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: Likely both. Anyway... (hands Trumbo a check) ...for the defense fund.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: (hesitates) You working again?

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: Eh. It’s a little slow. (to Trumbo) I'll be fine, kid, take it. Trumbo does, reluctantly, then:

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: You sold one. Cleo looks at the wall and sees a discolored space. There were six paintings; now only five.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: The Renoir. I got a good price. Trumbo is moved beyond words -- a rare occurrence. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 36.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Eddie, I... (overcome ) ---well... I...

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: What he’s trying to say is, he loves you.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: (to Cleo) I love him, too, the warty son of a bitch. (then, to Trumbo) Oh and I got a great offer on the Monet, if you want to bribe the jury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the JURY FOREMAN reads:

dialogues.speaker: JURY FOREMAN
dialogues.text: In the matter of the United States versus Dalton Trumbo... Trumbo stands at the bar, next to attorney Robert Kenny. JURY FOREMAN (CONT’D) ...we find the defendant guilty of contempt of Congress. He was ready for this, but the reality hits hard. His eye betray just a flicker of agony. Then, aware of all the stares, his battler’s armored visage returns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo and Kenny exit the courtroom in a river of COURT F

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: I have total contempt for Congress, I just thought a jury’d see why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo and Kenny fight their way through the clinging PRE (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 37.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT KENNY
dialogues.text: (to Reporters) The Supreme Court will drop kick this verdict into speeding traffic and end the most shameful chapter of Congressional history I ever want to live through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo and Kenny.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT KENNY
dialogues.text: How're you doing for money?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Broke as a bankrupt’s bastard. Why?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT KENNY
dialogues.text: You owe me thirty-thousand dollars. The appeal’s gonna be twice that.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Well, better get to work.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT KENNY
dialogues.text: Doing what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo writes furiously on his typewriter. The sounds of LAUGHTER pierce his CLATTER. He looks up at the window, t rises, crossing to it.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE WINDOW
dialogues.text: Cleo on the driveway, where a ping-pong table’s been set She’s teaching Niki, 4-year-old Mitzi and Chris how to pl the game. There is much GIGGLING amid the missed shots.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMBO WATCHES,
dialogues.text: Silently separated from his family by the sheet of glass. Then he has to let the curtain drop back across the windo Back to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One light on. Trumbo’s study.  TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arlen Hird lies in a weakened, post-surgery stupor. His e open and he sees Trumbo setting down some flowers.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: How are you?

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: Breathin’. With one lung. Which is half as good as two. How bad’re things out there?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Everybody envies you. Hird looks around the pleasant, private room.

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: Why not. Got the best room in the joint. You oughta know, you paid for it. (then, woozy) Thanks. By the way. Trumbo smiles at Hird, whose eyes flutter shut.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY ROSS, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: Mayer's a dinosaur... Over the streamlined entrance, a steel-sculpted banner: R INTERNATIONAL PICTURES.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY ROSS, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: ...-they all are, extinct and don’t even know it. INT. ROSS INTERNATIONAL - BUDDY’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS Enormous and pristine.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY ROSS
dialogues.text: Let’s see now, to, uh... Buddy, Trumbo and other MOVIE-INDUSTRY COMPATRIOTS raise champagne glasses in the winter of 1948. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 39. BUDDY ROSS (CONT’D) .»..to no more MGM, no more Mayer, I am strictly independent, got cans of film, wads of Wall Street dough and my favorite boss -- me! (all CHUCKLE, CLINK, sip, then to Trumbo) And you, you crazy son of a bitch, are gonna write all my movies, once this Washington crap clears up. A throat is CLEARED. Trumbo is a bit more pensive than we seen him.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: And how’ll that happen?

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY ROSS
dialogues.text: Hey. I’m not political. Thank Jesus. But if they called me in, accused me? I’d just say, yep, did it, sorry, didn’t mean it. Trumbo nods, willing to move on. But somehow just can’t h himself.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: (evenly) So Congress asks, “Are you now or have you ever been a Democrat...?”

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY ROSS
dialogues.text: “I am... and God, I just feel awful about it, never again...”

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: But now they want the names of other Democrats. (points at random MEN) Bill... Stan... Earl... Nat.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY ROSS
dialogues.text: Then I say go to hell.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Really. And how many banks fund enemies of the state? Your money's gone. Unless you give the names of your friends here. They’1ll never work again. But it’s the only way you ever will. (then) (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 40.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We’re all friends here, we all know each other... we hope. What would you do, Buddy? Buddy stares, chilled. Silence. Then --

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY ROSS
dialogues.text: Piss on the best day of a guy’s life! Only you! BIG LAUGHS all around. But from those four men Trumbo singled out, nervous ones. And from Trumbo, not so much a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo hard at the keys, surrounded by full ashtrays, pil of typescript and a half-empty scotch bottle. He pauses t shift in his seat and twist his aching back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lies on the couch, scotch on his chest, pillow under h back, scribbling on typed copy, still in some pain. Niki, almost _11 now, walks in wearing her nightgown.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Morning, Nikola.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: I thought you weren’t allowed to write anymore.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: No. Just can’t put my name on it or get paid.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: How’s that work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Niki eats a sundae, watching Trumbo and Hunter as the lat thumbs a dog-eared screenplay with scribbles on many page and bold handwriting on the cover.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: IAN MCLELLAN HUNTER
dialogues.text: (the script) It's funny, breezy, romantic. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 41.

dialogues.speaker: IAN MCLELLAN HUNTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (then, sarcastically) Who the hell wrote it?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: You did, old boy. Stick your name on my labor, hand it in to your studio and --

dialogues.speaker: IAN MCLELLAN HUNTER
dialogues.text: Look, it’s just dumb luck I wasn’t subpoenaed. The hearings’re gonna start up again soon, I’m gonna get called and canned...

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Then quick, lad, let’s sell this little beauty and split the take, fifty-fifty.

dialogues.speaker: IAN MCLELLAN HUNTER
dialogues.text: Ridiculous. I’11 take ten percent.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: You'll take twenty. No, thirty. That's my final offer.

dialogues.speaker: IAN MCLELLAN HUNTER
dialogues.text: You are the worst businessman, ever. (then) I hate the title.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: Me too. She gets a sharp look from her father that drives her bac her ice cream.

dialogues.speaker: IAN MCLELLAN HUNTER
dialogues.text: I mean, The Princess and the Peasant... (scribbling on the cover) .»».sounds like a puppet show.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Change it.

dialogues.speaker: IAN MCLELLAN HUNTER
dialogues.text: I did. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He slides the script across the table to Trumbo, its new title atop the cover page’s handwritten notes, in bold fe and circled. Trumbo’s distaste for it is immediate.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Now, who the hell’s going to go see a movie called Roman Holiday? INT. U.S. CAPITOL —- ROTUNDA - DAY Congressman Thomas moves with a small CLUSTER of many of same REPORTERS from Scene 30, all now his acolytes --

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN THOMAS
dialogues.text: .--I’m going to introduce legislation so in the event of national emergency, all Communists will be sent to internment camps...

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 2
dialogues.text: Does the president support this?

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN THOMAS
dialogues.text: He'd better. Stripling now appears at Thomas’ shoulder, WHISPERS in hi ear as he shows him a sheaf of monetary columns. Both Stripling’s hushed, unheard words and the document’s sheet get Thomas’ full attention. CONGRESSMAN THOMAS (CONT’D) (to the Reporters) Excuse me, gentleman. He and Stripling peel off, away from the Reporters. CONGRESSMAN THOMAS (CONT’D) I’ve told you, Bob, these are legitimate, salaried employees from my home state --

dialogues.speaker: STRIPLING
dialogues.text: What you didn’t tell me is, every one of them is a relative.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSMAN THOMAS
dialogues.text: Which is completely legal.

dialogues.speaker: STRIPLING
dialogues.text: Except none of them have paid taxes. (as Thomas tries to explain) (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 43.

dialogues.speaker: STRIPLING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t say anything else without a lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cleo gets out of her car, carrying mail and The L.A. Time She walks past a half-finished addition, abandoned at framing. She scans the front page of the paper.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: (suddenly shaken) +. NO... JEFF, their contractor, sun-baked, 30s, has been waiting.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF THE CONTRACTOR
dialogues.text: Mrs. Trumbo? Ma’am, I gotta get paid. She looks up, truly at a loss. JEFF THE CONTRACTOR (CONT’D) Please, I got men with families.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Jeff. We owe everyone. But my husband can’t get work. Before Jeff can respond, Trumbo speeds up in his car and skids to a stop and bounds out with two bottles of champa

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: (ecstatic once again) We're rich!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo signs a check with a flourish and hands it to Jeff

dialogues.speaker: JEFF THE CONTRACTOR
dialogues.text: Thanks. You sure lead exciting lives. Boy. He pockets it as Trumbo reaches for the champagne.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: It sold, Cleo, Roman Holiday, Paramount, credited to our dear Hunter and what, what’s the matter?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Justice Rutledge died. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 44,

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: No, Justice Murphy, last --

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: And Rutledge. This morning. She hands him the Times. As he reads, she holds him. INT. ROBERT KENNY’S LAW OFFICE - CONFERENCE ROOM - DAY

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT KENNY
dialogues.text: The two most liberal judges on the Supreme Court... Trumbo, a still-frail Arlen Hird and members of The Ten s solemnly before a heartsick Kenny. ROBERT KENNY (CONT’D) .+-back to back. This is just... He lets it hang in the air. A long, ten-man silence.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Well. I’11 be goddamned if I know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: One upside, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT KENNY
dialogues.text: Our appeal’s gonna be denied. You're all going to prison. INT. ROBERT KENNY’S LAW OFFICE - ELEVATOR - DAY Trumbo helps Hird in. Hird pushes the button, then leans his cane. Both men stare straight ahead as they descend. As sick as Hird is, Trumbo is paler. He looks gutted. The CLANKING descent seems eternal. Then:

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: I wouldn't change a thing. Not one. Would you? Trumbo considers this carefully before:

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Let’s ask each other in a year.  TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: June, 1950. NO SOUND at first, just MUSIC as Trumbo, Cleo Niki, Chris, 9, and Mitzi, now 5, cross the tarmac to a waiting DC-3 prop passenger plane. Suddenly aware of --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CROWD gathering at the edge of the light, moving toward them. Then, TWO PEOPLE raise a banner, the words spread o on a sheet between two poles:

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO IS GOING TO JAIL
dialogues.text: The crowd closes around the surprised Trumbos. Hands are offered and shaken. More signs raised. More PEOPLE cluste Cameras are brought out and --

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Slightly embarrassed, is surrounded by family, well-wishe and more huge, handwritten signs bearing his name and pli

dialogues.speaker: MINUTES AFTER THAT
dialogues.text: Capturing the final, sad moments of Trumbo’s goodbye: - Tiny Mitzi hugs Trumbo. She can’t be pried off. - Trumbo whispers into Chris’ ear:

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: I’m counting on you. Your mother needs to laugh. Once a day. At least. Deal? Chris nods and refuses to cry. Father and son shake hands - Trumbo hugs Niki. DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) Don’t be afraid.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: I’m not. She's angry at herself for tearing up. Trumbo hands her h silk pocket square. - Trumbo kisses Cleo one last time on the lips. - Trumbo is led off by TWO U.S. MARSHALS. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 46.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: - Trumbo is up on the ramp of the plane. A FLASHBULB POPS The moment is FROZEN into an old sepia photograph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Trumbo family car rumbles home from the airport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the backseat, Niki consoles Mitzi. Up front, Chris rid alongside Cleo, who is driving. Everyone is grieving in their own way. Then --

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: (suddenly blurting) I was married before. Well, this certainly gets the attention of all the kids.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your father’s my second husband.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: Holy shit.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Niki...

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: Mom, gimme a break, you can’t just say that and not --

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: I’m saying it for a reason. When I met your father, I had a boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: What was his name?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Hal.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Hal. Heh.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: Did you love him?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: That’s not the point. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 47.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: What’d you think of Pop back then?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: I couldn’t stand him.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: So how’d you end up marrying him?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: I was waitressing. He came in for a hamburger, we talked a little, I brought him the check and he proposed.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Seriously? Cleo catches Niki’s look in the rear view, a smile that s that’s Pop.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: I said he was crazy but he kept coming back, night after night. Talking and talking. And the tips! On a ninety-cent check, he’d leave ten dollars! After a year, I had over a thousand dollars. I saved every penny, I wasn’t going to let him think he could buy me. But... also... I just, I’d never met anyone like him, ever, I couldn't stop thinking about him. And guess who didn’t like that much?

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: Hal.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Hal. Who got mad, then jealous, then went and got a wedding license and a judge.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: That must’ve made Pop mad.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: No. He just asked if I could see myself with Hal in twenty years and I burst into tears -- I couldn’t see myself with him for twenty more minutes. He was big and crude and had all these rules... (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 48.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (then) Your father was such a good friend, I'd never had anyone like him in my life... and do you know what he did? Hired a private detective.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: And found out Hal was already married. All the kids let out LAUGHS and SHOUTS and pound the seat They love seeing this new side of their mother.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: Mom, how could you not tell us this before? This is great!

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: I’m telling you now because when he did all that, your father proved when he believes in something... or someone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Large, remote, set amid thick green Kentucky forest.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (POST-LAP)
dialogues.text: .--it doesn’t matter what anybody else thinks, says or does... INT. ASHLAND FEDERAL PRISON —- PRISONER PROCESSING - DAY

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (POST-LAP)
dialogues.text: .--he will try, fail... Trumbo is naked, along with a GROUP of prisoners who are undergoing a body and cavity search by GUARDS. fTrumbo is stoic. CLEO (POST-LAP) (CONT’D) .--fall down, get up, fall again. But never, ever give up.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: So don’t waste your time being mad at the people trying to stop your father. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 49.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (smiles) Feel sorry for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a blazing summer afternoon, Trumbo off-loads 50-pound slabs of frozen beef rib from a truck, balancing one on h shoulder, sweating and moving past TWO PRISON GUARDS.

dialogues.speaker: PRISON GUARD 1
dialogues.text: (mid-story) ...so he files a complaint, says I don’t treat him fair.

dialogues.speaker: PRISON GUARD 2
dialogues.text: Nigger said that?

dialogues.speaker: PRISON GUARD 1
dialogues.text: So warden says I gotta do right. Boy wanna better job? I put him in charge o’ the whole goddamn supply room. ‘Cause I know somethin’ the warden don’t. Nigger can’t read! Finally, Trumbo gets his huge side of beef to the pallet manages to drop it. He stands, soaked, catching his breat There’s a sharp pain in his back. He tries not to let it show.

dialogues.speaker: PRISON GUARD 2
dialogues.text: (laughing) Can’t read, that’s good!

dialogues.speaker: PRISON GUARD 1
dialogues.text: Serve the jig and warden both right, supply gonna be a goddamn mess!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very much a mess. Reports and records in random piles and sloppy stacks. But also a cool, dark basement relief from the swelter above. A wrung-out Trumbo hands a clipboard to a powerful, sever black man named VIRGIL BROOKS.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Beef’s unloaded. Driver needs a signature. Brooks nods and takes the clipboard. Without really looki he scribbles a line near the bottom of the page. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) Actually, he needs it... here. Trumbo points to the still-blank signature line. signs again. DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) If you could use help, I used to be in shipping, at a bakery.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKS
dialogues.text: I heard you was a writer.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: That, too.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKS
dialogues.text: And a Commie. (with a hard look) Fuck is wrong with you people? This is a great country.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Agreed. Well, he tried. Heads out.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKS
dialogues.text: You type?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Eighty words a minute.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKS
dialogues.text: Bullshit.
Brooks With two fingers, copying off a rule book. Brooks glances his watch and chops the air. Trumbo stops.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKS
dialogues.text: Now if only I could read it. (then, off typewriter page) “Protocol as to return of goods: There shall be triplicate copies of form 14-A filed with Supply, Shipping and office of the warden.” Trumbo looks up at Brooks, surprised. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 51.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You think you gonna teach me the alphabet so I shake your hand all grateful ‘n’ say, “Thankee Missuh Trumbo, you done changed mah life, suh, I never fuhgit you.” (then) This ain’t no movie and I ain’t Mr. Bojangles. I got twenty years for killin’ a white man tried to rob my bar, I did it and I’d do it again. Look down on me and I will fuck you up like you never been fucked up in your whole bullshit Beverly Hills life. I’m here to build my time and get paroled, you wanna help make that happen? Brooks hefts a box of files onto the desk with a THUD.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Welcome to fuckin’ Supply, comrade. INT. ASHLAND FEDERAL PRISON —- PRISONER DORM - NIGHT 1951. One of the few prisoners still awake, Trumbo sits o his cot in a single cone of light, scribbling on a pad.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (starting a letter) Dear Cleo. INT. LAZY-T RANCH - CLEO’S DARK ROOM - DAY

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I don’t count the days or hours. I count the seconds. She switches the red light off and opens the shades. Summ sun REVEALS developing equipment and dozens of photos hun dry. All of the children: fishing, on horseback, playing tag, sitting for a group portrait.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Sometimes I think I’ll die of boredom. Other times, fear. As she inspects each critically, she passes something we don’t expect: a boxer’s speed bag hanging from the ceilin which she gives a single, light WHACK without looking.  TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Immaculately organized now.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Not of this place. Trumbo sits, dutifully typing at top speed.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So far... Prison Guard 1 enters, shocked at the crispness of the ro

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...its challenges are all surmountable. Augmented by days of lovely boredom, so flat and calm in the wake of all that churning, ugly, luckless battle. -- and the report Brooks writes with a fuck-you smile.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No, my fear is for what will happen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cleo is playing a furious game of ping-pong against both Chris and Mitzi --

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...-when I get out. To our family... -- while Niki sits nearby, absorbed in a copy of the Dail Worker, with its headline: “NEW COMMUNIST HOLLYWOOD HEARI BEGIN.”

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .«..and our country. INT. ASHLAND FEDERAL PRISON - MESS —- DAY

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Not all the national news is worrisome. Some reminds me that what the imagination can’t conjure, reality delivers with a shrug. Nearly deserted but for Trumbo as he enters with a sheaf reports, crossing past a lone figure mopping the floor: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 53.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Congressman J. Parnell Thomas, wearing a prison uniform identical to Trumbo’s. He stops mopping. Trumbo pauses in doorway. The two men regard one another.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And reality has delivered, in all its beatific wonder, to the federal penal system, former Congressman and head of HUAC, J. Parnell Thomas. Convicted of tax evasion. Thomas goes back to work. Trumbo’s eyes linger on Thomas the former inquisitor dips his mop then swabs the floor.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Proving the truism... Trumbo deposits his sheaf on a table top and exits.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “,..Character is destiny.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a sunny morning, her three children eating breakfast around her, Cleo finishes this letter.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yet in all this, I know I’m the luckiest unlucky man ever to live... because you and the children warm, feed, clothe, pacify and rejuvenate me, by never leaving my heart. Love, Prisoner Number 7551. She touches the paper tenderly, gets up and moves to shoeboxes that overflow with Trumbo letters, adding this

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All chairs face a screen as Trumbo and SEVERAL HUNDRED PRISONERS and GUARDS watch a war movie.

dialogues.speaker: UP ON THE MOVIE SCREEN
dialogues.text: Plays a gung-ho soldier, barking orders amid backlot GUNF

dialogues.speaker: BACK DOWN IN THE AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: Trumbo smokes and watches. Sitting next to him, Virgil Brooks is totally caught up in the war drama.  TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo, Brooks, Prisoners and Guards walk back to the dor

dialogues.speaker: BROOKS
dialogues.text: You know John Wayne?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKS
dialogues.text: What’s he like?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: You'd love each other.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: It was, in fact, an enormous, brown, stucco hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near the front door, the MAITRE D’ slides Hedda’s coat on

dialogues.speaker: A MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ‘Scuse me? Are you Hedda Hopper? She turns and sees a YOUNG ENLISTED MAN in an army unifor awkward, nervous, respectful, whose empty right sleeve is pinned up. He’s lost an arm.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: I -- yes, hello, how do you -- ? She holds out her right hand, is instantly mortified, but Enlisted Man clasps her right with his left.

dialogues.speaker: ENLISTED MAN
dialogues.text: I don’t mean to bother you, I’m here with my cousin, he’s a gaffer at Columbia? Thought he’d treat me to the big time. I read you a lot, all the guys do. Not just the showbiz stuff. You get what’s really going on, with Russia, the Commies here, the investigations. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: Where did you serve?

dialogues.speaker: ENLISTED MAN
dialogues.text: Korea. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 55.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: And you’re how old...?

dialogues.speaker: ENLISTED MAN
dialogues.text: (proudly) Next month I’1l be twenty. She has no words, just looks at this boy, struck to her c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: March, 1951. An Appaloosa horse stands against the mounta range, lazily dipping its head to chew grass, then raisin to scan the horizon. Nearby, Cleo focuses her camera on the majestic animal. S CLICKS off several shots. Chris is nearby, holding spare film canisters and lenses.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Mom.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Mm?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I've got a new one. She glances at Chris, who uses his hands to shove his che in toward each other -- then smiles, making his mouth kin a chubby vertical smile. Cleo chuckles and aims her camer at him.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mom! She turns. Her daughter is at the back door of the main house.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You better come quick! INT. LAZY-T RANCH —- LIVING ROOM - DAY Chris and Cleo enter, Niki crouched in front of the enorm radio, dialing a clearer reception.

dialogues.speaker: STRIPLING, (ON RADIO)
dialogues.text: ...ever been a member of the Communist Party? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 56.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON, (ON RADIO)
dialogues.text: I am not now nor have I ever been a member of that party, no... INT. U.S. CAPITOL - CAUCUS ROOM —- CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: ..-I have always been a liberal Democrat. Robinson is in the same seat Trumbo occupied. But no long a packed circus, it is now a rehearsed degradation ceremo Robinson speaks into radio microphones splayed before him he looks into the eyes of Investigator Robert Stripling.

dialogues.speaker: STRIPLING
dialogues.text: But in your home, over the years, there have been political meetings. Attended by those we now know to be Communists.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: Yes sir, yes, that has now been made clear to me... there were tremendous activities that went on in my house during the war...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cinder-block Texas facility on a brown, scrubby flat.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON, (ON RADIO)
dialogues.text: ..-but I did not know then their true affiliations... the work they were up to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arlen Hird lies in a bed among A DOZEN other infirm PRISONERS, hearing through an old oaken radio:

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON, (ON RADIO)
dialogues.text: ...the lies... Most of these prisoners could not care less -- but Hird i gravely riveted by Robinson’s testimony. EDWARD G. ROBINSON (ON RADIO) (CONT’D) ...the deception.  TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
