dialogues.text: Most PRISONERS ignore the hearing CRACKLING on a small ra but a FEW, including Virgil Brooks and Trumbo, listen. Congressman Thomas, wiping down tables, is far away... bu listens intently, glancing occasionally at -- Trumbo, stony, a flicker of sadness in his eyes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- as Robinson’s eyes harden, a man determined --

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: I was duped and used. I was lied to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Cleo’s eyes close. The kids are transfixed.

dialogues.speaker: STRIPLING, (ON RADIO)
dialogues.text: Who used you? INT. U.S. CAPITOL - CAUCUS ROOM —- CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: Well, these... sinister forces who ran these... organizations in which I became a member, these.... uh, so- called Communist fronts.

dialogues.speaker: STRIPLING
dialogues.text: Tell us the names of individuals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo and Thomas, across the room from one another, both wait.

dialogues.speaker: STRIPLING, (ON RADIO)
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Mr. Robinson? INT. U.S. CAPITOL - CAUCUS ROOM —- CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: Well, you had Albert Maltz, uh, Ring Lardner, Jr., and that top fellow who they say is the, uh, commissar out there... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 58.

dialogues.speaker: STRIPLING
dialogues.text: Arlen Hird?

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arlen Hird is unflinching as he hears --

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON, (ON RADIO)
dialogues.text: .--Arlen Hird. Waldo Salt, Ian McLellan Hunter.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON, (ON RADIO)
dialogues.text: And Dalton... -- as is Trumbo --

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: ...Trumbo. -- Robinson feels relief, hoping this is all now behind h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brooks looks at the radio, disgusted, as we hear --

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON, (ON RADIO)
dialogues.text: But at the time, it never entered my mind that any of these people were Communists...

dialogues.speaker: BROOKS
dialogues.text: (to Trumbo) That guy’s a friend of yours? (no response from Trumbo) Lucky he’s out there. And though he speaks to Trumbo, he speaks at Thomas:

dialogues.speaker: BROOKS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Snitch like that in here, you’re fuckin’ dead. Trumbo leaves a terrified Thomas with a smiling Brooks.  TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 59.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BUSTLING. CROWDED. Edward G. Robinson is seated. Waiting. His eyes flick to a closed door. Stenciled on it: JOHN WAYNE, PRESIDENT. INT. MOTION PICTURE ALLIANCE - WAYNE’S OFFICE - CONTINUOU Wayne, Roy Brewer, Hedda and a FEW OTHERS meet.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN WAYNE
dialogues.text: Eddie oughta go back to work, he did what he had to.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: He did what he was forced to.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN WAYNE
dialogues.text: Point is, he did it.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: Brave men are fighting this battle, sacrificing in ways we can’t even imagine, and you talk about some asshole’s “career”? I’d see Eddie Robinson and everyone like him dead if it’d bring one boy back from Korea. One.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN WAYNE
dialogues.text: So what’re you saying? Guys like Eddie cooperate and get nothin’? (then) That isn’t right.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: Careful, Duke.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN WAYNE
dialogues.text: Or what, Hedda? They stare at each other, neither moving or blinking. JOHN WAYNE (CONT’D) If I’m not careful. What? The room is frozen, cigarette smoke the only moving thing Then Hedda breaks the tension with a quick smile.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: I had no idea you were such a softie. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 60.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Wayne studies her, then allows himself a grin.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN WAYNE
dialogues.text: That’s me. All cuddles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wayne walks Robinson out.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN WAYNE
dialogues.text: I’m proud of ya, Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: (flat, far off) Thanks, Duke.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN WAYNE
dialogues.text: Wasn’t easy, I know, but ya did good. I’m gonna call the studios, the offers’1ll pour in. (off Robinson’s mute nod) Y’ okay?

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: Sure. Thanks. And tell Hedda... (beat) Give her my love, willya?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN WAYNE
dialogues.text: Not sure she'd know what to do with it. That is one hard broad.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSREEL FOOTAGE
dialogues.text: Of the end of the ROSENBERG espionage trial. The Couple h been found guilty of selling atomic secrets to Russia and sentenced to death, then...

dialogues.speaker: NEWSREEL FOOTAGE
dialogues.text: Of SENATOR JOSEPH McCARTHY’S rise as he purports to uncov Communists throughout the United States.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spring, 1951. The same room where Trumbo was stripped nak and examined upon his entrance. Now he is back in his sui tie and overcoat. His wedding ring, lighter, cigarette ca and holder are returned by a GUARD.  TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 61.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A taxi idles. Cleo waits. A SILHOUETTE approaches on the other side of the closed gate, which RUMBLES open, reveal Trumbo, now free. Cleo smiles, they move into one another last and kiss, then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Trumbo drowns in the hugs of Chris, 10, and Mitzi, 6.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Giants! What have you huge, beautiful strangers done with my little ones? Niki appears in a dress. Tall. Almost 13. A young woman. DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) Good God. (as he moves to her) Lipstick?

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Da-aaad. He takes her hands and kisses her cheek. Then the five reunited Trumbos move into the house, REVEALING: A “FOR SALE” sign on a fence and tacked across it: “SOLD. INT. CHASEN’S - DAY CROWDED. Trumbo enters and sees Arlen Hird at the far end the bar, makes his way to him, as a KNOT OF BUSINESSMEN c his path. Trumbo bumps one.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Pardon me, I’m terribly -- It’s Buddy Ross. Trumbo is delighted. DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) Buddy. How are you? Buddy is highly aware of the men in his group, watching h

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY ROSS
dialogues.text: (to Trumbo, icy) I got nothin’ to say to you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 62.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Buddy turns and strides off, followed by the men, all of WHISPER to each other. INT. CHASEN’S - AT THE BAR - LATER Trumbo and Hird sip their cocktails.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: So. Jail’s given us the plague.

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: Buddy was always an asshole. He glances into the restaurant dining area, where he can Buddy animatedly making a pitch to that group of men.

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And he’s in trouble. Three movies, three flops. (re: Buddy’s sweaty chatter) Look at him. Tryin’ to sell his soul but can’t find it. Just hope he stays afloat long enough to get the shit sued out of him.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: By whom?

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: You, me, all of us, go on the offensive this time, sue the studios, all these guys, use their own capitalist system against them, in civil court -- make ‘em admit under oath --

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: -- No, no, no, Jesus, haven’t you spent enough time in court? I have.

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: What do you, got a better idea?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Do the one thing everyone says we can’t. Work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo crosses a courtyard of slouching palms and tobacco colored bungalows, the offices of: KING BROTHERS PICTURES (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 63.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK KING, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: Look. You're a great writer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo sits across from a beefy, harried, vaguely menacin man in his 40s named:

dialogues.speaker: FRANK KING
dialogues.text: -..we make shit. I don’t see it.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Mr. King, I’m a screenwriter. If I couldn’t write shit, I’d starve. On the walls, lurid posters of King Brothers movies: star free gangster, horror, sci-fi and western quickies.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK KING
dialogues.text: We can’t afford you.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: How much did you pay for the script of... (points to western poster) ...that?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK KING
dialogues.text: Twelve-hundred bucks.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: I'll write you a movie for twelve hundred, then.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK KING
dialogues.text: And you don’t want your name on it.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: No, you don’t want my name on it.

dialogues.speaker: HYMIE KING, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You got that right... And in a corner WE REVEAL Frank’s younger brother, HYMIE, owlish and clenched with worry.

dialogues.speaker: HYMIE KING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ..-especially if you’re still... y'know... up to stuff. Are ya?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Perpetually. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 64.

dialogues.speaker: HYMIE KING
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK KING
dialogues.text: Got any ideas?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Well, I just got out of prison, how about crime? The story of a gangster, his rise and fall?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK KING
dialogues.text: I've seen that a few times.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Because it always makes money.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK KING
dialogues.text: And when do I get the product?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: (rising) Three days.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK KING
dialogues.text: A hundred page script in three days? You tryin’ to fuck me? You fuck me and I will fuck you --

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Mr. King, I’ve heard this speech. It was better in jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo writes, cigarette fuming like a factory chimney. T shelves are stripped, moving boxes piled everywhere. He arches, his back hurting so much he actually stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo is naked in the tub again. He adds scotch to his coffee and scribbles on typed scripts, pain-free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo waits in the room’s only guest chair. A CURVACEOUS RECEPTIONIST hunts flies with a swatter. A door jerks open and a flushed Frank King stands hugely the doorway, holding a script. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 65.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK KING
dialogues.text: Are you kiddin’ me with this? Trumbo looks up at him, alarmed. The Receptionist freezes mid-swat. Frank lunges at Trumbo, grabs his right hand, shakes it hard, then YELLS into another doorway: FRANK KING (CONT’D) Hymie! Get out here! Pay the man! Hymie emerges, pulls out a roll of cash, peels off fiftie FRANK KING (CONT’D) Now look, we got this one, killer in a swamp? Best character’s the swamp. Plus, women in prison, fighting in their underwear -- it’s perfect except it stinks. (to Hymie) What else?

dialogues.speaker: HYMIE KING
dialogues.text: Pirates. Can’t afford the ocean.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK KING
dialogues.text: Fix ‘em all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1952. A working-class section of Los Angeles. Small, neat houses; older cars. On this Sunday, MEN in sport shirts t to both, while WOMEN walk baby carriages or trim flowers KIDS play. A moving truck RUMBLES past, followed by --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. /EXT. TRUMBO’S CAR - DRIVING/HIGHLAND PARK - CONTINU Trumbo at the wheel, Cleo beside him, the three kids in b all taking in this new block. Trumbo’s gaze settles on a presidential election lawn sig EISENHOWER/NIXON, featuring photos of the two candidates. Trumbo focuses on Nixon’s wide grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovely, compact. MOVERS unload furniture from their truck Niki pours lemonade for some who take a break.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: Hard work, you holding up okay?  TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 66.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beside a shimmering pool, Trumbo and Mitzi tend to a tiny injured bird. She is upset, Trumbo warmly calm.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: It’s a broken wing but he’s going to be just fine, sweetie.

dialogues.speaker: MITZI
dialogues.text: He’s scared.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: We'll get him some water, some nice, yummy worms, go inside, ask mom for a shoebox. She runs into the house. Trumbo cups the bird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house has been completely moved into. Cleo comes down the stairs in a bathing suit.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: C'mon, Mitzi! Mitzi races down the stairs, also in a bathing suit. Moth and daughter cross through the house, excited. They pass YAWNING Trumbo still in his robe. He opens the front door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- to get the paper and lying next to it, sees a plain envelope. Trumbo picks it up and opens it. It reads in block letter

dialogues.speaker: WELCOME TRAITOR. WE DID THE POOL.
dialogues.text: Alarmed, Trumbo hurries out to --

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS
dialogues.text: -- where Cleo comforts Mitzi, upset as Trumbo exits the h to see -- -- their pool fouled with garbage, dirt, floating dead ra Trumbo immediately moves to his wife and child.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: All right. Inside. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 67.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He glances across his fence and sees his NEXT-DOOR NEIGHB 30s, tight white t-shirt, watering his lawn. And an unmistakably big, shit-eating grin on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo presides over the family dinner.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: There are many ignorant, angry people in the world. And they appear to be breeding in record numbers. All we can do is stay together and remain vigilant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fall, 1953, as WE FIND the bright marquee, announcing: Roman Holiday. Starring Gregory Peck and Audrey Hepburn. Below that, a lit poster for the breezy romantic comedy. TIGHT on the movie’s credits and ISOLATE: Original Story by Ian McLellan Hunter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Among the ROWS of MOVIE FANS, Dalton and Cleo Trumbo enjo lovely, funny scene, LAUGHING with the rest of the audien though perhaps with a bit more restraint.

dialogues.speaker: IAN MCLELLAN HUNTER, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: Big hit, great reviews -- INT. DINER —- DOWNTOWN L.A. - DAY

dialogues.speaker: IAN MCLELLAN HUNTER
dialogues.text: -- haven’t worked in nine months. Trumbo sips coffee. Hunter reaches for the cream.

dialogues.speaker: IAN MCLELLAN HUNTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: There aren’t quite enough zeroes in a King Brothers salary to survive --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo at the typewriter, surrounded by empty shelves. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 68.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -- but they need scripts like an army needs food. Quality, minimal; quantity, maximal.

dialogues.speaker: THIS OFFICE MORPHS OVER THE YEAR
dialogues.text: As Trumbo writes, never leaving the desk, as if chained. WITHOUT A SINGLE CUT, all around him, the shelves fill wi scripts, the office growing more and more cluttered.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Every work week is seven days, every day is fourteen hours, every minute I’m behind. And I’m becoming a stranger in my own home.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO
dialogues.text: INT. DINER —- DOWNTOWN L.A. - DAY

dialogues.speaker: IAN MCLELLAN HUNTER
dialogues.text: They need five of you. Trumbo smiles slyly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of FIVE MEN, including Ian McLellan Hunter and Arlen Hird Though they’re sipping cocktails and coffee, they have th clenched look of people in the middle of a job interview. Which is not far from the truth because --

dialogues.speaker: FRANK KING, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The only question is, can these pinkos write?

dialogues.speaker: SEVERAL TABLES AWAY
dialogues.text: Sit, the Kings looking over the table of writers like use goods at a garage sale:

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: (points) That’s Ian McLellan Hunter.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK KING
dialogues.text: (impressed) Guy wrote Roman Holiday.

dialogues.speaker: HYMIE KING
dialogues.text: Guy just got subpoenaed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 69.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK KING
dialogues.text: Guy just got nominated.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Everyone at that table’s been nominated. Frank nods. A waiter delivers drinks as a BUXOM STARLET bends to whisper to Frank, who nods, kisses her hand, sen her along. Hymie looks faintly ill with dread. DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) It'd be like this... I find the writer and work with him. He delivers the script to me. If it’s good, I'll give it to you, if it’s bad, I'll fix it. Nobody gets paid till you're happy.

dialogues.speaker: HYMIE KING
dialogues.text: (scared, whispers) And these writers are... all... all, uh...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK KING
dialogues.text: Blacklisted, Jesus, you’re such a chickenshit.

dialogues.speaker: HYMIE KING
dialogues.text: Y'know, we’re at war with the Communists.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK KING
dialogues.text: No, we’re not.

dialogues.speaker: HYMIE KING
dialogues.text: It’s a new kind of war.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK KING
dialogues.text: Yeah, doesn’t exist, very new.

dialogues.speaker: HYMIE KING
dialogues.text: What about the Rosenbergs?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK KING
dialogues.text: What about ‘em?

dialogues.speaker: HYMIE KING
dialogues.text: They stole the atom bomb.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK KING
dialogues.text: They didn’t steal it off a fuckin’ camera truck. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Four of the five writers try to appear blandly appealing. Only Arlen waves, coquettish. Hunter throws him a glare. FRANK KING (CONT’D) (to Trumbo, earnestly) Look. We bought a gorilla suit. And we gotta use it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hird, Hunter and the other blacklistees confer with Trumb

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: So you had five jobs, now we got ‘em all and you got none?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: I’m now free to go get five more jobs and five more writers. Then you each get five more jobs, five more writers --

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: To keep that going, we’d need to write every script in the business.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: (faux innocence) What a thought, Arlen. Lord, you're a devious lad. (then) So who wants to write a gorilla movie?

dialogues.speaker: IAN MCLELLAN HUNTER
dialogues.text: Who doesn’t?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo stands. His wife and three children sit.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: We now work at midnight, in thick fog, among strangers. The four Trumbos stare at him, all confused. DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) Not... literally. (then) We’re running a family business.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 71.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We’ll be adding new phone lines. A phone on a table. Then ANOTHER DISSOLVES IN alongside i Then ANOTHER. One RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When you answer, never say “Trumbo residence,” just -- Chris, 12, picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Hello. A MAN’S VOICE (ON PHONE) Is John Abbott there?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Whoever they ask for, find me or --

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: No, sir, may I take a message? He listens as he writes a message for “John Abbott.”

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: The door must be answered at all hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DOORBELL CHIMES. Mitzi, 8, opens it. A UNIFORMED MESSENGER stands, checking a clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: MESSENGER
dialogues.text: Got a pickup from... Sally Stubblefield? Mitzi checks a side table stacked with large envelopes, f the one marked “Sally Stubblefield” and hands it to the Messenger. MESSENGER (CONT’D) Can I get your dad to sign? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 72.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She scribbles on the clipboard like a pro and shuts the d

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Dictation, short hand and typing will be learned. Those of legal age will have one of the most important jobs imaginable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A scruffy little independent company.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Courier. Cleo’s car pulls up, she exits, moves to a delivery entra The door opens. A WOMAN’S HAND holds out an envelope. INT. TRUMBO’S CAR - MOMENTS LATER Cleo checks the envelope, fat with twenty-dollar bills.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: (to his family) Questions? Comments? Niki raises her hand.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: Is there a schedule?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: A what.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: I need to know when I can do homework. And I’m on a fundraising committee for Negro Voting Rights, plus --

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: All right, honey, we'll work it out. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 73.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (as Trumbo begins to object, she throws him a look) Won't we. He doesn’t answer. Trumbo and Niki lock eyes in uneasy silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Niki watches a bulky new television set, the picture jitt ON TV —- AFRICAN-AMERICAN PROTESTERS In actual black & white news footage MARCH outside school

dialogues.speaker: TV ANCHOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .--and protests continued as the Supreme Court takes up the issue of racial segregation...

dialogues.speaker: NEARBY, TRUMBO TYPES
dialogues.text: Then pulls rough copy from his carriage and holds it out Niki, but she is riveted by --

dialogues.speaker: TV ANCHOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .--while throughout the nation, heated debate over integration... -- until she sees the page he proffers, SIGHS, takes it, moves to a second typewriter and begins HAMMERING out the final carbon, her eyes straying to the TV images of PROTE

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: Trumbo is alone, the TV is off. Trumbo opens a drawer, ta out a pill bottle, shakes out one tablet, then decides tw would be better. As he pops them in his mouth, Cleo appears in the doorway question on her lips. She sees her husband down the pills with a shot of scotch. She quickly decides the question c wait and retreats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hunter, Hird and Trumbo sit as Frank King gives “notes.”

dialogues.speaker: FRANK KING
dialogues.text: (picks up a script) Which one’s “Graham Topper”? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 74.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The three writers look at one another, unsure. FRANK KING (CONT’D) Nympho nun. Ah. Hunter raises his hand. FRANK KING (CONT’D) Great job. He hands Hunter his script back. FRANK KING (CONT’D) “Elwood Carr”? Murder at the circus? Trumbo nods, King slides him the script. FRANK KING (CONT’D) Needs work. I knew it was the clown.

dialogues.speaker: IAN MCLELLAN HUNTER
dialogues.text: (consoling Trumbo) It’s always the clown. Now King levels a malevolent gaze at Hird.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK KING
dialogues.text: So. You’re the alien and the farm girl.

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK KING
dialogues.text: You wrote... He opens the script to the middle, showing pages and page and pages of single-spaced, typewritten speeches. FRANK KING (CONT’D) ...the alien talking about “the rights of workers,” the “pathology of capitalism”? (enraged) The “dialectic”? I don’t even know what that IS and I fucking hate it.

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: All right, so it’s a little dense -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FRANK KING
dialogues.text: I pay for a script about a guy with a giant bug head balling a girl in a haystack, you give me shit that’1ll get me subpoenaed. And also? Stinks! (then) Never. Again. Fix it. But that last was not to Hird, it was to Trumbo. As King shoots the script across the table at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hird and Trumbo go over Hird’s screenplay.

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: Oh, fuck Frank King.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: (scribbling in the script margins) I said, until he’s happy, I rewrite.

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: So you’re gonna stay up all night with this crap, to what, get it to his high literary, political standards?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: It shouldn’t be to anyone’s political standards. What the hell were you thinking...? Hird snatches Trumbo’s pen. Trumbo glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: I was thinking. It’s why I'ma writer. To say things that matter. Jesus Christ, look at us. (then) I was a reporter, I got nominated for a Pulitzer, I fought in Spain! I know Ernest Hemingway! I actually, I know him! And he knows me! I walk into a bar in Paris, he’d -- maybe he doesn’t know my name but... (then) You won the National fucking Book Award. What're we doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 76.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Trumbo stands and moves to the bar. He takes two glasses.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: The two men, several drinks in, fairly hammered, trying t work.

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: So the alien... the alien... why does he... want to impregnate the farm girl? To start a race... propagate, so they can all take over...

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: (shakes head) She's cute. Hird considers this solemnly. Then --

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: Uh. Fine. (a defeated pause) I mean, don’t you ever miss writing something, forget great, just good? You gotta have actual ideas... still... don’t you? Trumbo smokes. Then:

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: A few. One keeps buzzing around up there... won’t go away. Cleo and I were in Mexico at a bullfight, years ago. Bull died and... a thousand people cheered. Three didn’t. Cleo, me... and a little boy down front. Crying. I always wondered why.

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: You write it, you'll know. Just, promise me, not for Frank King.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: The day I don’t have to and just want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spring, 1954, Oscar Night, the Trumbos, minus Niki, eat snacks and chat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 77.

dialogues.speaker: MITZI
dialogues.text: Niki! Hurry! The sound of a toilet FLUSHING, then feet running.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: (racing in) Who's doing it?

dialogues.speaker: MITZI
dialogues.text: Kirk Douglas! As they all settle and watch their black & white TV --

dialogues.speaker: ON TV
dialogues.text: 38 years old, chiseled and dashing in white tie and tails

dialogues.speaker: KIRK DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: ...the envelope? And the Oscar goes to... (pulls out the card) .--Roman Holiday! By Ian McLellan Hunter! The THEME from Roman Holiday and APPLAUSE, while Douglas scans for the writer who will never appear.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Sit for a moment, not sure how to react to this, until --

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: So, do we get to be happy now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo, Hunter and between them: that gold Oscar statuett

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: I don’t want it.

dialogues.speaker: IAN MCLELLAN HUNTER
dialogues.text: Well, I don’t want it.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Your name’s on it.

dialogues.speaker: IAN MCLELLAN HUNTER
dialogues.text: You wrote it.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: They gave it to you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 78.

dialogues.speaker: IAN MCLELLAN HUNTER
dialogues.text: And it’s done me wonders. (hands Trumbo a script) Here’s the gorilla movie. Chris enters.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Phone for you, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Which name?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: No. You. Some guy named Buddy Ross. Trumbo is surprised as he picks up the extension.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: (teasing, into phone) Buddy who...? INT. ROSS INTERNATIONAL - BUDDY’S OFFICE - NIGHT This is not the Buddy Ross we've known. He vibrates with exhausted panic as he takes a seat near Trumbo.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY ROSS
dialogues.text: So’s it true, the rumor? You wrote Roman Holiday? Trumbo just looks at him, then --

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: What can I do for you, Buddy? Buddy hesitates, barely knowing where to begin.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY ROSS
dialogues.text: My movies’ve all bombed, dug me into a hole. I finally got something going. Classy. Three big stars. The script... (he can’t finish) What script, there’s no script, I got eleven writers who fucked me, now the actors’re gonna pull out ‘n’ if they do, I lose everything.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: When do you shoot? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 79.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY ROSS
dialogues.text: Ten days.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Is there anything? He hands Trumbo three typed pages. Trumbo studies them.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY ROSS
dialogues.text: There'd be no credit, obviously, I can’t pay you till we start shooting, and I wouldn’t blame you if you spit in my face. But we did good stuff, back then, we really did. Please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo and Hird.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: I owe the Kings a rewrite, I can’t do both, I need you to take over.

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: So you can help out that great guy, Buddy Ross.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: So we can keep tearing down the blacklist.

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus, here we go...

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: This is a huge movie, if Buddy gets a good script --

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: -- which you’re gonna give him --

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: -- which I’m going to sell him.

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: Yep. Money. Always money. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 80.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Why do you not see this? We get one big movie, we could get all the big movies and the whole rotten thing’1l collapse from the sheer irony that every unemployable writer is employed.

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: Jesus, do you ever say anything that isn’t gonna get chiselled on a rock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near an open window overlooking the back patio, Cleo drie some dishes at the sink. Trumbo and Hird’s ARGUMENT can b heard but is muffled by doors and walls. Cleo HUMS to herself, as nearby -- Chris cleans his trumpet, while Mitzi tends to another wounded bird. Mitzi catches Cleo’s eye and -- Cleo smiles and TOSSES a water glass into the air, then a second, then a third, JUGGLING them. Mitzi LAUGHS with delight, Chris smiles then --

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (suddenly loud) .-.-I am not gonna help you help Buddy Ross! The kids are startled --

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: We should be suing that cockroach into the ground, along with every studio, congressman, producer --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- as is Cleo, who manages to keep the glasses aloft --

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (exploding) Brilliant -- !  TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 81.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: -- keep losing, give all your money to lawyers --

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: I'd rather lose for the right reason than --

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: (roaring)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cleo’s deft hands flutter, a glass FUMBLES off her finger and HITS the floor in an EXPLOSION of shards -- INT. TRUMBO HIGHLAND PARK HOUSE —- STUDY - CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: It’s LOSING!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cleo sweeps her children out.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: C'mon, kids, we're going to the store.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (to Cleo) But --

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I lose -- !

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: (to her kids) Now.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: -- you lose -- !

dialogues.speaker: MITZI
dialogues.text: Which store?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: -- we ALL lose -- ! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 82.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Any store. Cleo’s calm but sharp demeanor is not to be ignored. The kids follow her out. INT. TRUMBO HIGHLAND PARK HOUSE —- STUDY - CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: -- and the whole goddamn country stays scared and dead! You want to live like this forever? Or do something? We can beat them, we can win!

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: I don’t care if I win --

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: -- Oh, bullshit, everyone wants to win --

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: No, you wanna win, I wanna change things.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: I want to win so I can change things --

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: No, you want the Oscar you can’t have and the money you burn through writing shit for idiots.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Why do I have to explain everything like you’re a fucking child? A beat, as Hird retreats quietly...

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: You don’t. Okay? You don’t. (heads for exit) Do what you do. It’s fine. For you. Trumbo, sensing he’s perhaps gone too far --

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: (calming) Arlen... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 83.

dialogues.speaker: ARLEN HIRD
dialogues.text: I know what I’m fighting for. You want another lake. And you know what? You’re gonna get it. Hird is gone. Trumbo is alone in the sudden quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo sits, still and silent, smoke curling off the cigarette in his fingers, staring at a blank typewriter p

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tub is full of hot water, Trumbo is in there, writing about half-speed, pausing every few words to smoke and ru his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cleo drops off a script to the Secretary, gets the cash envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo in the tub again, writing at top speed as WE RACK FOCUS TO that pill bottle we saw in his office. And REVEA here it’s Benzedrine. From downstairs, he can just barely hear CHEERFUL FAMILY VOICES --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Niki, just turning 16 now, blows out the candles on her birthday cake. APPLAUSE from Cleo, Chris and Mitzi, all hugging her.

dialogues.speaker: MITZI
dialogues.text: You sure we shouldn’t go knock?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: I’m sure. Niki stares at her smoking candles, angry.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: He can’t take five minutes -- ?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: (testing) Two minutes. One minute. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 84.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Chris. Get the good plates.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: I’ll do it. She exits and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- parks herself outside the closed bathroom door. She hesitates, then KNOCKS. The typing STOPS.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: Dad? We’re having birthday cake. The door flies open and there’s Trumbo, soaked, half-in h robe, enraged.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: When I’m working, you don’t knock!

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: But it’s my --

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: You don’t knock! Ever!

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: So the house is on fire, you don’t want to know?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: I work in a BATHTUB! Surrounded by WATER! So even if the whole WORLD catches fire --

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: (raging at Niki) -- I can still be this family’s personal goddamn SLAVE and all I ask is not to be interrupted for every fucking slice of FUCKING CAKE you see fit to -- ! Cleo appears, slicing a look into Trumbo that shames him silence. He takes a breath, all is still, then he SLAMS t door and is gone. Niki, terrified and humiliated, runs do the hall, crying. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 85.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Cleo stands, unsure what to do. She lifts her hand to kno on the bathroom door, again hears TYPING and thinks bette it. She then follows the sound of her daughter’s SOBS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bone-tired Trumbo heads for the master bedroom. Through the open door, he sees the bluish flicker of a black & wh TV and some familiar words from long ago... EDWARD G. ROBINSON/”MANNY” (V.O.,
What do you want? What we all want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo enters, sees Cleo watching an old movie on TV. It’ the one from MGM, 1947. Trumbo is transfixed.

dialogues.speaker: ON TV
dialogues.text: Smoothly acted, shot and cut together under lush MUSIC: EDWARD G. ROBINSON/”MANNY” (ON TV) To not die young, poor or alone. “ROCCO” (ON TV) Manny, these guys... I don’t give ‘em what they’re after, they’ll kill me. “Rocco” starts to go. EDWARD G. ROBINSON/”MANNY” (ON TV) Hold it, Rocco. “Manny” takes out his revolver -- and aims it at “Rocco,” freezes. EDWARD G. ROBINSON/”MANNY” (ON TV) (CONT’D) If we don’t fight these guys, sure, maybe you get that long, happy life we all want... but your eyes never really close again... ‘cause you spend that life scared of every noise in the dark. We both do. (beat) I can’t let you do this, Rocco... so I just have to convince you I’m right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 86.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Then -- “Manny” TWIRLS the gun with practiced 6lan, so he now holding the barrel as he HANDS it to “Rocco,” butt-fi “Rocco,” thrown and relieved, takes it. EDWARD G. ROBINSON/”MANNY” (ON TV) (CONT’D) (grins) After all, kid, what’re friends for?

dialogues.speaker: TRUMBO AND CLEO BOTH WATCH, NEVER LOOKING AT EACH OTHER
dialogues.text: As she’s taken back to that simpler time a decade ago. INT. TRUMBO HIGHLAND PARK HOUSE - NIKI’S ROOM - NEXT DAY She is still enraged. Her mother KNOCKS.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: Don’t defend him, okay? He knows he’s wrong, he just doesn’t like that I saw it before he did.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: I think he was just surprised. To see another adult in the house.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: He has to be right, all the time. How do you stand it?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Well, there are times... especially lately... (beat) C'mon. INT. TRUMBO HIGHLAND PARK HOUSE - CLEO’S DARK ROOM - DAY Cleo and Niki stand at that speed bag, hanging from the ceiling. Cleo JABS it once, it bounces, she JABS again, it bounces faster, then again and again and again and again and to h daughter’s amazement, Cleo is as expert as a pro.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: Do you imagine that’s his head?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: No. Cleo stops. Offers Niki a chance. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 87.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But you can. Niki hesitates, then crosses over, lifts her fist and -- INT. ROSS INTERNATIONAL - BUDDY’S OUTER OFFICE - DAY Niki crosses past SECRETARIES and CREW in a whirl of pre- production. She delivers the script to Buddy. He takes it kisses it with a LOUD SMACK. He holds his hand out to sha hers but she’s already turned to exit, stone-faced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo KNOCKS on a peeling door, soon opened by an earnes YOUNG MAN.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: I'd like to see Arlen Hird?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: I’m Andrew, his son...

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: (shakes hands) Dalton Trumbo. I’m certain your father’s said awful things about me, I assure you they’re all true but I’ve opted for early senility and forgotten everything, so...

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HIRD
dialogues.text: Mr. Trumbo... The young man pauses, unsure how to go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cheap closed casket. His son Andrew sits in the front row. Next to him, a YOUN BROTHER. Both wearing yarmulkes. And behind them, row aft row, all empty. And in the very back, Trumbo sits with Ia McLellan Hunter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hunter and Trumbo shake hands with the two Hird boys. And reaches into his coat.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HIRD
dialogues.text: Dad left something for you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 88.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He hands a small ledger to Trumbo.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HIRD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A record... money he owed you, some other people. I’m sorry, I wish we could pay you back. Trumbo is moved, shakes his head, lays a hand on the boy’ shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: No, Andrew... no. I owed him. The debts are all mine. INT. EDWARD G. ROBINSON’S MANSION - LIVING ROOM - DAY Trumbo waits alone, admiring Robinson’s magnificent and h collection of French Impressionists. Where before there w five or six paintings here, now: Over twenty famous works of art crowd the spotlit walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robinson enters, pauses in the doorway with his BUTLER, n for him to leave, then gathers himself, striding in.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: Well.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Hello, Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: This is a bit of a surprise... What, uh... what can I do for you? Trumbo takes an envelope out.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Arlen died.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: I heard, I was on location. Trumbo offers the envelope. Robinson just looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: He left a record of his debts. (the envelope) This is the money you gave us. For the defense fund. It’s everything we owe you. Arlen included. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 89.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: No, now that was a gift --

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: We'd like it off the books.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: What is this supposed to be, some kind of message? What you and Arlen and the Great Hollywood Ten all think of me? Trumbo lays the envelope on a table and starts to go. EDWARD G. ROBINSON (CONT’D) Fine. Fine. But first, you’re gonna listen. Trumbo pauses. Robinson gathers himself. EDWARD G. ROBINSON (CONT’D) After you went to jail, I didn’t work for a year. No offers, not even an audition. People’d see me, cross the street, people I loved, people I made rich. (then) I sat in front of that Committee... why? I didn’t do anything, none of us did anything, we were just stupid babies, with no business in any of it! (long beat) I just wanted my life back. They had every name -- yours, Arlen’s, everybody's, I didn’t give them anything they didn’t already have, I ended it, is all, I just... ended it.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Eddie, you don’t end something like this by giving them what they have no right to ask for.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: You’re gonna tell me how I shoulda handled it? Like you handled Congress?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Are you proud of what you did, is that what you’re saying? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: Proud? Who the hell gets to be proud? You! With your fake names and fronts, got all the work you want, I gotta go out in the world, every day, this -- (his own face) -- is my work -- I got no one else to be, I did what I had to --

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: (comes at him, hard) You did what you wanted. And you did it for more! More movies, more money, more dead bullshit on your walls! Robinson is pale and shaken. Trumbo takes a step back. Tries to calm himself. Starts to go.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: What I did, I did. But you get to wonder how many years you hacked off Arlen’s life to show the world what a rebel genius you are. Live with that. INT. ROMANOFF’S - NIGHT Trumbo downs a shot at the stylish, CROWDED industry wate hole as the BARTENDER pours him another.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Drinking alone? He turns. She smiles. A beat as he adjusts to her presenc

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Preferably. You?

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: Work. What’re you up to these days?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: You know, Hedda, one more... (downs his next shot) ---and I just might tell you.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: Then I’m buying. (signals for two more) Come on, I hear the rumors. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 91.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Show me you’re still in the game, fighting the good fight. (lowers voice, leans in) Rub my face in it. Whisper a movie you've written in secret. Maybe I've even heard of it.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Maybe you have. A familiar face breaks through the CROWD --

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY ROSS
dialogues.text: (to Hedda) Sorry, sorry, sorry, I’m shooting, it’s crazy, I -- He sees Trumbo and freezes. Hedda clocks that.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: Buddy. You know Dalton Trumbo. A long pause as the two men look at one another.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: We worked together. (then) At MGM. A million years ago.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: (to Buddy) I hear the script for your new one needs work. Hire Dalton, he used to be pretty good... and price-wise he'd be bargain basement. The Bartender brings the two shots.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Trumbo) Of course, you’d never. Not after Buddy named names. Trumbo tries to hide his surprise. And almost succeeds.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You didn’t know? Mm-hm. Word was, he’d hired someone he shouldn’t have. So he got subpoenaed, testified. Closed session, no press. Makes it easier. (beat) He named you, of course. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now he’s been cleared. Gets to go make his movie. In a way, thanks to you. 92. Buddy looks like he’s being turned on a spit. Trumbo down his shot and exits as he SLAPS a bill on the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAP! A below-the-fold headline is SLAPPED onto Trumbo’s desk by Niki, highlighting the headline: “CONGRESSMEN DEMAND RACIAL SEGREGATION” “'Negroes Have No Federal Right To Equality,’ Say Leading Democrats”

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: (appalled, angry) Can you believe it? Trumbo is at his desk, sliding pages into a manila envelo as Chris waits, wearing a sport coat and tie, and Niki ra a clipboard of signatures she holds.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Democrats. Voting for segregation.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: (correcting) Southern Democrats.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: Here’s the petition. (her clipboard) I’ve already got over a thousand signatures.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: (signs) Happy to make it a thousand and one. (hands Chris his envelope) And the new draft. I need it delivered to Hymie King in Agoura.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Wait, I thought the Kings, in Hollywood. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 93.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: No, these are the rewrites, being shot tonight, Hymie needs them on set, now.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: Agoura’s fifty miles.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: I’m sure Chris knows that.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: Well, he can’t --

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: -- excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: He has a date. (to Chris) Tell him.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (hating this) I...

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: (to Chris) Is she your girlfriend? Is it serious? Does she have some objection to romantic Agoura?

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: He’s taking her to a movie.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: All right, Nikola, then you deliver the pages.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: I have a protest. (the clipboard) For this.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Since when do protests have hard start times -- ?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I'll do it --

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Niki. Will do it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: I said, I can’t --

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Young lady, you will --

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: (her clipboard) -- this is important --

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: (his envelope) -- so is this --

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: This is important to me -- the date’s important to Chris -- figure something else out --

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: -- I’11 tell you what I’ve figured out, that under this roof resides a moody, self-righteous malcontent.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: Yep. We all live with him. She coolly exits past a rattled Chris, and as the hall, passes Cleo, who’s been listening. can’t see Cleo, nods for Chris to pick up the does so obediently, and also exits the study.. protective gaze. She has now made a decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One light on, upstairs.
she turns in Trumbo, who scenes. Chris + under Cleo’s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo enters in his pajamas. Cleo, in robe and slippers, sits by the window, looking out.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: She hasn’t been gone that long and it’s not that late. This is a blatant attempt to manipulate worry.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Do you know when I realized I had to leave Hal? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 95.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: (beat; thrown; then) Hal, Hal who?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: My first husband.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: (struck) Jesus Take The Wheel...

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: It wasn’t when you hired that detective... or asked me if I really loved him... because by then we both knew the answer was no. (then) It was my wedding night. (to clarify for him) My first wedding night. With Hal. Nothing about this turn in the conversation is anything h ever expected.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: If we’re going to travel back in time to that unholy coupling, I have a medical obligation to drink. And he heads for a small tray of glasses and scotch on th bureau top, pouring himself three fingers.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: I saw this was not a man I could have children with. He’d bully me, them and we’d end up like every miserable family since forever. But I knew you’d never be like that. Whatever went on out there, the only thing that’d matter, really matter, was us.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: All that matters is us --

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: No, not anymore, you have no idea what you could lose --

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: My career, the first amendment, the country? Am I missing anything? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Us, you're losing us. Since prison, you don’t talk or ask, just snap and bark -- I keep waiting for you to start pounding the dinner table with a gavel --

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: So in addition to being a pariah out in the world, I now have the supreme joy of battling insurrection --

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: -- please, “insurrection” --

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: -- in my own home, where these ten fingers literally feed, clothe and shelter us --

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: This isn’t just happening to you. We all hurt! Niki, me, your friends --

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Friends, what friends? Who the hell has the luxury of “friends”? I’ve got allies and enemies, there’s no room for anything else!

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: (quietly) We know. Believe me.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Good, then this discussion ends.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: This isn’t a discussion, it’s a fight. And this ends it: I will not let our children be raised by a bully -- any bully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Niki sits with THREE AFRICAN-AMERICAN TEENAGERS. Leaning against the table, the handwritten signs from their prote All the kids chat animatedly, then stop... seeing a sombe Trumbo approach.  TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 97.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo exits with Niki. Then she stops.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: I didn’t want to fight in front of my friends but --

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: -- I’m not here to fight --

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: -- I’m not coming home. She folds her arms and stands. He pauses, then speaks carefully, quietly, almost hesitantly.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Your mother is a quiet person. (dry) Normally. (then) The effect of which is... she can actually make me hear myself... and lately, it’s not a sound I like much. Because what I hear mostly is just... how afraid I am. This is not what Niki expected. She softens, listening. DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) Afraid this is scarring you, all of you... and what if it’s all for nothing? How do I live with that? (then) So I fight. It’s all I know how to do anymore, just... rage... at anyone in my way. (looking tenderly at her) But you’ve never been in my way, Nikola, not once... and never could be. Tears in her eyes now, she leans against him, allowing hi put one arm across her shoulders and kiss her head.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: It’s crazy how mad you make me, since all I ever wanted is to be just like you...

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: You are. Which I wouldn’t wish on anybody.  TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 98. INT. KING BROTHERS - FRANK’S OFFICE - DAY Frank sits at his desk -- across from Roy Brewer.

dialogues.speaker: ROY BREWER
dialogues.text: We know. Okay? It’s a small town and the gossip’s always true. (then) Fire Dalton Trumbo and the rest of ‘em or you got pickets, headlines and boycotts. We will put you right out of business.

dialogues.speaker: ROY BREWER
dialogues.text: Motion Picture Alliance for the Preservation of American Ideals. Me, Ronald Reagan, Hedda Hopper, the guilds, studio heads. John Wayne.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK KING
dialogues.text: I love John Wayne.

dialogues.speaker: ROY BREWER
dialogues.text: I'll introduce you. You guys could do a movie together.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK KING
dialogues.text: That’d be great, only... Frank King rises, holding a baseball bat. FRANK KING (CONT’D) .--I don’t think you and me are gonna be pals. King swings viciously and SMASHES a lamp. Brewer covers u SCREAMS and goes for the door. Locked. Frank comes at him FRANK KING (CONT’D) You gonna stop me hiring union? I'll go downtown, grab some winos and hookers, there’s my next cast ‘n’ crew! It doesn’t matter! I make garbage! He swings and SHATTERS a poster. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 99.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: FRANK KING (CONT’D) Wanna call me a pinko in all the papers? Do it! Nobody who goes to my movies can fuckin’ read! Another tight swing and he BLASTS a second poster. FRANK KING (CONT’D) I'm in this for the money and the pussy and they’re both fallin’ off the trees. Take that away from me. Frank jams the tip of the bat into Brewer’s throat. FRANK KING (CONT’D) Go ahead. I won’t “sue” you. But this -- (the bat) -- will be the last fuckin’ thing you see when I beat you to fuckin’ death with it. Brewer just stands, hyperventilating with terror. Frank T the door with the bat and it opens from the outside. Roy Brewer bolts --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- tears across the room, passing Hymie and practically tripping over a seated, startled Dalton Trumbo and -- -- Brewer glances at Trumbo, acknowledging the writer wit disbelief as he tumbles out the door.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK KING
dialogues.text: Fuck do you want?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: New script.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK KING
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Family film, something I’ve been mulling for a while. About a Mexican boy and his pet bull. (hands it to him) One problem. TIGHT ON the title page: The Brave One. By Robert Rich. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 100.

dialogues.speaker: KING
dialogues.text: Expensive?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Worse. Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fall, 1956. Hundreds of eyes drink in the vivid color:

dialogues.speaker: UP ON THE SCREEN
dialogues.text: The Brave One’s opening credits. Stirring MUSIC. Vibrant Mexican imagery of a boy and his bull.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: Amid a sea of clean-cut ‘50s FAMILIES WITH KIDS and a FEW YOUNG CALIFORNIA-CASUAL COUPLES we find:

dialogues.speaker: THE FIVE TRUMBOS
dialogues.text: Dalton, Cleo, Niki, Chris and Mitzi, munching popcorn, as

dialogues.speaker: UP ON THE SCREEN
dialogues.text: The writing credits appear and we see: Original Story by Robert Rich. CLOSE ON DALTON TRUMBO’S FACE And that writing credit is reflected in his glasses -- as tattooed across his eyes, marking him: Robert Rich.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Looks down and adjusts the pleats of her dress until the credit passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo, stone-frozen with shock, is on the phone:

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Who told you? (beat) What else did they say? Cleo appears in the doorway. Sensing something. DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) You, too. Goodbye, Frank. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 101.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He hangs up. Cleo is tense with dread.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: The Brave One was nominated for an Academy Award. INT. KING BROTHERS - FRANK’S OFFICE - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: FRANK KING
dialogues.text: No, Hymie, this is nothing like Roman Holiday. Frank, Hymie and Trumbo are gathered. FRANK KING (CONT’D) Roman Holiday had a guy with a name and a body they could give the award to. There is no Robert Rich. If it wins, who gets the thing?

dialogues.speaker: HYMIE KING
dialogues.text: Well, maybe it won’t. I mean, it’s not that good. (to Trumbo) No offense.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: None taken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spring, 1957 and another Oscar telecast, on a slightly la black & white TV screen. Trumbo, Cleo, Chris, Niki, and Mitzi are all assembled once again. Tense. Expectant.

dialogues.speaker: ON TV
dialogues.text: Sparkling with sexy sophistication (in actual footage of telecast) as she takes the card from the envelope --

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH KERR
dialogues.text: The Brave One! Robert Rich!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An agitated Roy Brewer is pacing, on the phone: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 102.

dialogues.speaker: ROY BREWER
dialogues.text: We're looking into it, we can’t find Mr. Rich anywhere, he apparently doesn’t -- (beat) No. Don’t print tha -- Suddenly, in the open doorway, a grimly hatted Hedda Hopp ROY BREWER (CONT’D) (hanging up) I gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: Who the hell is Robert Rich? And it had better not be who they say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1958. A playful Trumbo holds court before FIVE JOURNALIST

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Mr. Trumbo, are you Robert Rich? Did you write The Brave One?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: My policy is, never claim credit for any one movie. That way, it’s possible I had something to do with all of them. Except the stinkers, all written by my enemies. The Journalists all CHUCKLE and scribble, eating it up.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: What’s your position on the blacklist?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Well, on it. Along with thousands of others.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Are you using this Robert Rich controversy to try and end it?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: The Brave One's a nice little movie. If rumors of my involvement can sell a few tickets, then good. He sees Niki exit the house and approach. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Opened by TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 103. DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) And if the strange circumstances of its authorship can get a few questions asked, even better.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: (whispers) Dad? Sorry, some crazy guy on the phone says he’s Kirk Douglas.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMBO HIGHLAND PARK HOUSE
dialogues.text: Niki, revealing a tan, grinning, dimple-chinned --

dialogues.speaker: KIRK DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Niki? (holds out his hand to the stunned teen) Kirk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo settles into a chair across from Douglas.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Apologies. We’ve had more than our share of crank calls lately.

dialogues.speaker: KIRK DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: I can’t imagine.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: So.

dialogues.speaker: KIRK DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: So. I’m doing a new picture. And I just got the script. From a valise he hefts a document the size of a phone boo

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: That’s about seven hours of entertainment here.

dialogues.speaker: KIRK DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: And not a single page is entertaining. But there’s a good story in there, somewhere. About one man... (a knowing smile) ..-who tried to take on the whole world. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 104.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: You’ve got me so far.

dialogues.speaker: KIRK DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: He was a slave who led a revolt against the Roman Empire...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a nearby stool, we glimpse a water-dappled script cove

dialogues.speaker: SPARTACUS
dialogues.text: Screenplay by Sam Jackson Trumbo is in the tub, writing and talking on the phone:

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: «no, I can’t tell you what I’m working on now except to say, the blacklist is alive and well and so is the black market. (beat) Yes, you can quote me. Seeing my name in the paper drives certain people out of their minds... INT. PERINO’S RESTAURANT - NIGHT Hedda Hopper and Kirk Douglas greet with a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: Kirk, I’d like you to meet a friend of mine, Bob Stripling... HUAC Investigator Robert Stripling shakes Douglas’ hand.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...House Un-American Activities Committee. Drink?

dialogues.speaker: KIRK DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: No, thanks. You said it was important...

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: Only if you hired Dalton Trumbo.

dialogues.speaker: KIRK DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Who I hire is my business.

dialogues.speaker: STRIPLING
dialogues.text: No, Mr. Douglas. It’s ours. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 105.

dialogues.speaker: KIRK DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: STRIPLING
dialogues.text: We have to keep this country safe.

dialogues.speaker: KIRK DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: And how're you doing that?

dialogues.speaker: STRIPLING
dialogues.text: Why don’t I show you by putting you on the stand?

dialogues.speaker: KIRK DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Hedda, is your friend trying to scare me?

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: He’s trying to tell you the way things are.

dialogues.speaker: KIRK DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Maybe I don’t like the way things are.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: We've known each other a long time, Kirk.

dialogues.speaker: KIRK DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: We have.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: When did you become such a bastard?

dialogues.speaker: KIRK DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: (rises) Oh, I was always a bastard. You just never noticed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lustrous black Rolls Royce passes Trumbo’s t-shirted Neighbor in his driveway, working on a Ford, staring in m disbelief as -- The spectacularly out of place Rolls parks in Trumbo’s dr a CHAUFFEUR exits, opens the back door and -- A BALD MAN in Saville Row tailoring emerges. He views thi scrubby neighborhood as he does the world: with utter superiority.  TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 106.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bell ECHOES, Cleo opens the door and --

dialogues.speaker: THE BALD MAN
dialogues.text: (in a clipped Austro- Hungarian accent) I wish to see the man who wrote this. He holds up a copy of the screenplay Spartacus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo, in pajamas and robe, sits with a COCKATIEL. The B Man stands, wielding the rolled-up Spartacus script like cudgel.

dialogues.speaker: THE BALD MAN
dialogues.text: I am Otto Preminger. Beat. Trumbo rubs his tired eyes.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO PREMINGER
dialogues.text: (annoyed) The director.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: No, I know who you are, I just finished work a few hours ago.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO PREMINGER
dialogues.text: (the script) A copy of which I have read.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: I sent it in this morning, how -- ?

dialogues.speaker: OTTO PREMINGER
dialogues.text: I am Otto Preminger. The director.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Is it too early for a drink?

dialogues.speaker: OTTO PREMINGER
dialogues.text: Never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo, still in his robe, mixes drinks. Preminger studie strange contraption: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 107.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A homemade aviary of chicken wire, built out from an open window onto the lawn. In it, a new bird with a slightly b wing hops about, pecking at water.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: My youngest believes I can end the suffering of all broken birds.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO PREMINGER
dialogues.text: As can I. With a broiler. (accepts his drink) Are your duties completed for Mr. Kirk Douglas?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: I’ve got two weeks for Christmas...

dialogues.speaker: OTTO PREMINGER
dialogues.text: During which time you will work with me.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Will I.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO PREMINGER
dialogues.text: If you are as intelligent as your writing... and as greedy as your reputation. (then) It is an adaptation of the novel Exodus. You've read it?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO PREMINGER
dialogues.text: A colossal best-seller. Very nearly a perfect piece of shit. But —~

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: -- there's a good story in there, somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO PREMINGER
dialogues.text: Actually, I have no idea. But I have Paul Newman. INT. TRUMBO HIGHLAND PARK HOUSE - CLEO’S DARK ROOM - NIGH Cleo checks contact sheets as Trumbo fiddles with his cigarette holder, studying Preminger on their hall phone. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 108.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: You're doing it? Trumbo has a small, secret smile on his lips.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: I think it’s the only way to get him to leave.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: I know that smile.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: (faux innocence) Why, what ever do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Poor Mr. Preminger... thinks he’s the cat and you’re the mouse...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christmas morning, 1958. Under a glittering tree, Cleo, Niki, 20, Mitzi, 13, and Chris, 18, all unwrap presents a the tree, LAUGH and CHATTER. Trumbo sips coffee, digging into his stocking. Otto Preminger looms in the doorway, glancing at his watc

dialogues.speaker: OTTO PREMINGER
dialogues.text: Christmas? Is over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo walks Preminger to his study.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Did you read my new scenes?

dialogues.speaker: OTTO PREMINGER
dialogues.text: Dreadful. Keep up this level of work, I will see to it your name is on my movie. To take the blame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo sits, making notes on typewritten script pages. Preminger paces as he reads a new, clean script copy. He stops reading. He lowers the pages. He looks out the window. Trumbo studies him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 109.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO PREMINGER
dialogues.text: Better. Yes. But. There’s no other way to say it. It simply... lacks genius. Trumbo takes this in, amused and sanguine.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Otto. If every scene is brilliant, your movie will be utterly monotonous. Preminger takes this in with a thoughtful pause.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO PREMINGER
dialogues.text: I tell you what. (hands the pages back to Trumbo ) You write every scene brilliantly. And I will direct unevenly. Though amused, Trumbo starts to object when Mitzi enters with Kirk Douglas. Douglas is surprised Trumbo’s not alon

dialogues.speaker: OTTO PREMINGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Kirk.

dialogues.speaker: KIRK DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Otto. How are you? The two shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO PREMINGER
dialogues.text: I’m very well.

dialogues.speaker: KIRK DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: I, uh, don’t mean to interrupt --

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Not at all, you’1ll excuse us, Otto?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo and Douglas -- able to glimpse Preminger through t open study doorway.

dialogues.speaker: KIRK DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: I sort of feel like I walked in on my wife. Do you love him?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: It’s far more lurid than that. He’s paying for my services. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 110.

dialogues.speaker: KIRK DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: So am I.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: And you'll have me again, January second, as promised.

dialogues.speaker: KIRK DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: I just need you a few days on some the new scenes.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Not till the second...

dialogues.speaker: KIRK DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t ask but I’ve never had a director who’s a bigger pain in my ass than Stanley Kubrick. Worst part is, he’s right.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: And I wouldn't refuse, but... (he hesitates) This has to stay between us.

dialogues.speaker: KIRK DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Preminger has indicated... well, what he said was, “Keep up this level of work and I will see to it your name is on my movie.” Douglas isn’t so much surprised as slightly irritated.

dialogues.speaker: KIRK DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Really.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: His exact words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Preminger and Trumbo watch Douglas getting into his car outside.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO PREMINGER
dialogues.text: I suppose he wants you back? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 111.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: (reading script pages) Hm? No. Just came by to talk about, ah, screen credit.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO PREMINGER
dialogues.text: On Spartacus?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: I shouldn’t have said anything. You understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a piece of the slave gladiator training compound in background, SLAVE EXTRAS sip coffee and gossip with ROMAN SOLDIER EXTRAS. CREW MEMBERS adjust lights and tweak wardrobe. In a dark corner, Kirk Douglas, in costume as the rebel gladiator, confers with the boxy, no-nonsense head of Universal, ED MUHL.

dialogues.speaker: ED MUHL
dialogues.text: Hedda Hopper says the American Legion is going to boycott us unless you fire Trumbo.

dialogues.speaker: KIRK DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Ed, he’s not done with the script, his name’1ll never be on the thing, what’s anybody boycotting?

dialogues.speaker: ED MUHL
dialogues.text: Twenty-million Americans are saying loud and clear they will never buy a ticket to our movie unless you fire one writer. Muhl hands Douglas a sheet of typewritten paper.

dialogues.speaker: ED MUHL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here’s fifty. Pick one. INT. KING BROTHERS - FRANK’S OFFICE - DAY Central to the whole room now is a framed one sheet for T Brave One, announcing it as an “Academy Award Winner!” Fr stomps past, watched cautiously by Hymie and Trumbo. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 112.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK KING
dialogues.text: You can’t admit you’re Robert Rich, so twenty-seven people with twenty- seven lawyers all say they’re Robert Rich and we owe ‘’em money... ‘cause they wrote The Brave One. (tosses a thick document onto his desk) Five-hundred-thousand dollar lawsuit. (then another) Two-million-dollar lawsuit. And my favorite... (another) ...a teacher from Eagle Rock who wants eleven-thousand five-hundred dollars, plus mileage and meals.

dialogues.speaker: HYMIE KING
dialogues.text: We settle, we're wiped out. Confess, we get subpoenaed.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, I can say in all honesty, this I did not see coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo smokes alone, gazing into another perfect sunset, mulling this latest twist in the road.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Trumbo? Mind if I stick my nose in? He turns as she exits the house.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: He knows. She means their Neighbor in the white t-shirt, watering h lawn on the other side of the fence.

dialogues.speaker: NIKI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He sees Kirk Douglas in and out of here and Otto Preminger in his Rolls. He’s an idiot but he’s not stupid. (sits near Trumbo) Has he called the FBI? Congress? (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NIKI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No. Because everything they can do, they’ve done. (then) That Oscar belongs to you. Get it.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Good God, you’re nothing like me. (delighted) You're worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: January, 1959. News vans and equipment trucks clog the drive. Cables snake into the brightly-lit house. The Trumbos’ next-door Neighbor and OTHERS from the block sta and rubberneck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo and an INTERVIEWER are on camera in a blast of lig

dialogues.speaker: TV INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: For the record, you’re Robert Rich.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: I am. INT. KIRK DOUGLAS’ MANSION - KITCHEN - CONTINUOUS Douglas is on the phone. In front of him, Muhl’s list. Mo of the names have been crossed out. But a few are circled

dialogues.speaker: KIRK DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: (into phone) Yeah, he’d be all right, and I guess he’s free, interested... Nearby, the TV is on. Douglas can’t keep his eyes off it.

dialogues.speaker: TV INTERVIEWER, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: ...and you wrote The Brave One.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (ON TV)
