dialogues.text: I did. INT. HEDDA HOPPER’S MANSION - LIVING ROOM - CONTINUOUS Hedda, hosting a COCKTAIL PARTY, looks through a doorway her home office, where A FEW GUESTS are glued to the TV.

dialogues.speaker: TV INTERVIEWER, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Why come forward now?  TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 114. INT. TRUMBO HIGHLAND PARK HOUSE —- STUDY - CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: As someone who’s been thoroughly investigated by the House Un- American Activities Committee, I started wondering... INT. HEDDA HOPPER’S MANSION - HOME OFFICE - CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: ...why hasn’t anyone ever taken a good, long look at them? And their work in the movie industry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She approaches Trumbo’s TV face here in her home, her par guests as awkward as caught children. INT. OTTO PREMINGER’S HOTEL SUITE - CONTINUOUS Preminger dresses for dinner, half-watching:

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: They were convened to uncover enemy agents, expose Communist conspiracies and write anti- sedition laws. INT. KIRK DOUGLAS’ MANSION - KITCHEN - CONTINUOUS Douglas has the phone to his ear but is mostly watching:

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Now here we are, thousands of hours and millions of dollars later: agents uncovered -- zero; conspiracies exposed -- zero; laws written -- zero. INT. OTTO PREMINGER’S HOTEL SUITE - CONTINUOUS Preminger CHUCKLES, loving it. INT. HEDDA HOPPER’S MANSION - HOME OFFICE - CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: All they do is deny people the right to work and they can’t even get that right. Academy Awards -- (self) -- two. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 115.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: Mother-FUCKER! She HURLS her tumbler at the screen -- glass and liquid EXPLODE over Trumbo’s TV image. INT. OTTO PREMINGER’S HOTEL SUITE - CONTINUOUS -- Preminger HOWLS with LAUGHTER -- INT. KIRK DOUGLAS’ MANSION - KITCHEN - CONTINUOUS -- as Douglas hangs up the phone, silently transfixed.

dialogues.speaker: TV INTERVIEWER, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: And how does that feel? To have so undermined the blacklist it’s almost a joke?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: A joke. (contemplates this darkly) I know the blacklist that produced Robert Rich, I’ve seen its horror, cruelty and hideous waste of life as I’ve marched in the long line of its anonymous. INT. TRUMBO HIGHLAND PARK HOUSE —- STUDY - CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: I can’t invent one more witticism about Robert Rich or the Oscar he can't claim... because that small, worthless, golden statue is covered with the blood of my friends. Twelve years of this foul thing is enough. None of us should yield one more inch... or give them one more life. INT./EXT. PREMINGER’S ROLLS ROYCE/BEL AIR - DRIVING - DAY January, 1960. Preminger is in back, holding the script o Exodus, speaking into an elaborate mobile telephone of th era:

dialogues.speaker: OTTO PREMINGER
dialogues.text: I’ve read your latest draft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 116.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trumbo is just sitting down to breakfast. He has the Cockatiel.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: OTTO PREMINGER
dialogues.text: My answer is on the front page of today’s New York Times. Trumbo picks up one of several papers there. And is stoically astonished by a headline of January 20, 1960: “OTTO PREMINGER ANNOUNCES EXODUS WRITTEN BY DALTON TRUMBO He is without words as he fully takes this in. Then:

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: You hate it that much.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO PREMINGER
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas, Mr. Trumbo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Muhl enters the dark, empty room, FLICKERING with a ro cut scene of: Spartacus hurled against the wall by the African slave, DRABA, pinned with his trident. In a corner of the screening room, our Douglas is pleased picks up the phone. Notices Ed Muhl.

dialogues.speaker: KIRK DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Hi, Ed, hang on. (into intercom) Put up the speech before the big battle? (into phone) Warren, I’d like you to put out a press release, saying the screenplay for Spartacus was written by Dalton Trumbo. Thanks. Douglas hangs up. Ed Muhl doesn’t like this. One bit.

dialogues.speaker: ED MUHL
dialogues.text: Kirk. If you won't get rid of Trumbo, I will. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 117.

dialogues.speaker: KIRK DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: And right after I quit, you can reshoot all my scenes. See, Ed, for better or worse... I am Spartacus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hedda Hopper and John Wayne are both on stage, addressing THOUSAND LEGIONNAIRES.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: There’s a picture coming out. Starring Kirk Douglas. Written by Dalton Trumbo. HISSES and BOOS echo.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s called Spartacus. And don’t believe it if there’s some other writer’s name on it. We’re onto them! Aren't we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APPLAUSE and mounting CHEERS.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN WAYNE
dialogues.text: We sure are. ‘Cause it’s a new day! (the crowd ROARS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Muhl threads through the sleek industry CROWD, picks u phone at the bar:

dialogues.speaker: ED MUHL
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: Ed. Every theatre that movie is in’ll get picketed unless you pull the prints, tonight, and take that fucking traitor’s name off.

dialogues.speaker: ED MUHL
dialogues.text: Hedda, that’s expensive and pointless. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 118.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER
dialogues.text: Then kiss your movie, your studio and your miserable ass goodbye!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: October, 1960. The world premiere of Spartacus. (ARCHIVAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The movie has begun. Black-tie AUDIENCE eyes drink in:

dialogues.speaker: THE OPENING CREDITS OF SPARTACUS
dialogues.text: We hear the percussive SCORE and see the stunning titles.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMBO AND CLEO
dialogues.text: Sit a few seats from Kirk Douglas and his WIFE as --

dialogues.speaker: UP ON THE SCREEN
dialogues.text: Under the words “Screenplay by.” TRUMBO’S OWN NAME Is reflected in his glasses. And strikes him deeply.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: Grips her husband’s arm, holds her breath, savors this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Undressing, Trumbo hears a quiet SOB from across the room

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Cleo? She is at her vanity table, in her robe, CRYING. DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) What, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: It’s over, isn’t it.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Yes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: And we made it... (she can’t believe it) Jesus, we made it, didn’t we...

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: We did. His eyes glisten. They clasp hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: January, 1961, and below the marquee announcing Spartacus SIXTY OR SO MEMBERS OF THE AMERICAN LEGION picket. There a HEAVY POLICE PRESENCE. Suddenly, the doors of the theat open, disgorging MEN IN DARK SUITS protecting --

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT JOHN F. KENNEDY
dialogues.text: As REPORTERS close in around him (a mix of actual news footage and recreation), trying to get a comment --

dialogues.speaker: TV COMMENTATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: President Kennedy enjoyed a rare evening off, attending the new Kirk Douglas film, Spartacus. Breezing by the glowering Legionnaires, he’s asked --

dialogues.speaker: TV REPORTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It’s a very controversial film, what did you think?

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT JOHN F. KENNEDY
dialogues.text: It’s a, ah, fine picture and... INT. HEDDA HOPPER’S MANSION - HOME OFFICE - CONTINUOUS A hatless Hedda sits alone and watches:

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT JOHN F. KENNEDY, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: .--I think it’s going to be a big hit. Hedda turns him off, while on a glassy wall of her many magazine covers, sees herself in 1947 under the masthead:

dialogues.speaker: TIME
dialogues.text: As we hear the sound of POLITE APPLAUSE. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 120.

dialogues.speaker: MASTER OF CEREMONIES, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: ...this next award is given to that member who has advanced the literature of motion pictures. I am proud to present The Writers’ Guild of America Laurel Award...

dialogues.speaker: MASTER OF CEREMONIES
dialogues.text: +..to Dalton Trumbo. On March 13, 1970, the MASTER OF CEREMONIES is on the sta of a black-tie Writers’ Guild gala, where LIGHT CLAPPING greets an older but still spry Trumbo, who regards his aw with a mixture of gratitude and amusement, then:

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: (at the mic) Often, when I stand before the film community, there is an elephant in the room -- me. (mild LAUGHS ripple) I thought I might address that. (and begins his speech) The blacklist was a time of evil. As he speaks, voice echoing, WE CUT AROUND THE ROOM TO:

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: At a table, unchanged in her simple, radiant elegance. DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) And no one who survived it came through untouched by evil.

dialogues.speaker: WITH HER, CHRIS, MITZI AND NIKI
dialogues.text: Now grown, beaming, proud. DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) Caught in a situation that had passed beyond the control of mere individuals, each person reacted as his nature...

dialogues.speaker: IAN MCLELLAN HUNTER
dialogues.text: Listens with a sad and knowing smile. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 121.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) ..--his needs, convictions and particular circumstances compelled him to.

dialogues.speaker: THEN TRUMBO SEES EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: Staring stonily, almost daring the writer to continue. DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) (thrown, pausing, then) There was good faith and bad. Courage and cowardice. And we keep CUTTING AROUND THE ROOM TO:

dialogues.speaker: OTTO PREMINGER
dialogues.text: In all his shiny-domed glory. DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) Honesty and dishonesty.

dialogues.speaker: KIRK DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Still buffed to movie star perfection. DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) Selflessness and opportunism.

dialogues.speaker: THE KING BROTHERS
dialogues.text: Hymie, ever-nervous, and Frank, deeply gratified. DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) So when you look back on that dark time, as I think you should now and then, it will do no good to search for heroes or villains. There were none. There were only victims.

dialogues.speaker: AND NOW WE GO BACK TO EDWARD G. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: Disarmed, Trumbo’s compassion the last thing he expected. DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) Victims because each of us felt compelled to say or do things we otherwise would not. To deliver and receive wounds we truly did not wish to exchange. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NIKI
dialogues.text: In particular is moved by this. DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) That is why none of us -- left, right or center -- emerged from that long nightmare without sin. TRUMBO’S EYES AGAIN FIND ROBINSON And neither man looks away. DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) What I say here is not intended to be hurtful to anyone. It is intended to repair a hurt. To heal wounds which years ago we inflicted on each other and most of all... ourselves. (then) Thank you. And as the room RISES to give him a STANDING OVATION...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The once-bustling dream factory is weedy and deserted but a defiantly dapper Trumbo, saying goodbye to TWO YOUNG PRODUCERS who sport the era’s regulation jeans and beards As they move off, Trumbo pauses to light his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN WAYNE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Well, well. Trumbo turns to see John Wayne getting up out of a convertible: heavier, older, but still a mighty presence. JOHN WAYNE (CONT’D) What’re you doin’ here?

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: Working with some young producers.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN WAYNE
dialogues.text: Me too. (glares at Trumbo’s shaggy pair) Yours look just like mine. All growin’ the hair we’re losin’. (then) (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 123.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN WAYNE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I read in the paper. ‘Bout your award. Speech. Got me... Trumbo waits as Wayne picks his words carefully: JOHN WAYNE (CONT’D) Ya fight when ya have to... maybe not always the way ya want to. What I mean is...

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: I know what you mean. They stare at each other. Anything might be said, anythin could happen. After a long silence: DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) It’s a new day. And with those words, Dalton Trumbo holds out his right h John Wayne looks down at it... then clasps it in his own.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN WAYNE
dialogues.text: Each ‘n’ every morning. These two powerfully different men shake hands, then: JOHN WAYNE (CONT’D) Better mosey. My producers need a diaper change. You stay outta trouble.

dialogues.speaker: DALTON TRUMBO
dialogues.text: That I will not. Wayne concedes a smile as Trumbo strolls away, cigarette smoke wreathed around his head like laurel, vanishing int the shadows of a studio at twilight. FADE OUT.
